text:
{From 2011 notes}
12 oz bottle dated "best by" 3/2011 served in pint glass. Very small amount of sediment added mid-tasting. 

pours a clear copper with a moderate off-white head. Head has good retention.

This is a relatively hoppy APA that also has a robust malt base. High caramel component in both the aroma and flavor. Bold and crisp with excellent finish. The flavor is rich and a little earthy. Excellent sweet/bitter balance, with a mildly bitter close and aftertaste. Taste rating approaches 4.5.

O: This is about as good as an APA gets. Super choice to introduce macro-lager drinkers to a more flavorful craft beer or to prepare PA drinkers for an IPA.
Dark amber color. Big minerally nose with apples and oranges. Medium body modest bitterness. A throw back to the 90s pale ale. Ok

Bottle. Copper in colour. Hoppy; pine and grass. Fruity; tangy citrus grapefruit. Malty; bready malts, caramel. Nice hop/fruit/malt balance. Mild hoppy bitterness over sweet malts. Liked this. Very drinkable. (2010-12)

Fľaa z minipivovar.sk. Jantárová farba, biela pena. Pivo ialene penilo, aj keď bolo správne vychladené. Vôňa karamelová, citrusová. Chuť sladová, karamelová, tropické ovocie, citrusové tóny. Dlhá horká dochuť.
Amber color. Medium-sized, white head. Aroma of malt , fruits with herbal and citrus hoppy notes. Malt dominates in taste but closer to end hops take over. Moderate , hoppy bitterness.
0,33l bottle shared with wiosna @ Wilhelm. Pours clear golden with a medium head. Aroma is fruity malts. Flavor is fruity malts with some hops. Good balance. Good stuff.

12fl oz bottle @El Lúpulo Feroz, Oviedo. 01-02-2015.
Pours some hazy amber with nice off white head. Diacetyl, malty, caramel nose. Medium body, average carbonation, some oily texure. Taste is malty, caramel, some fruity.
Flaska. Klar guldfärgad med ett frostigt vitt skum. Dofter av malt, frukt, ljust bröd och säd. Smakinslag av malt, citron, säd och bröd. Avslutas med en lättare syrlighet.

355ml Flasche. Rot-braunes Bier mit hellem Schaum. Nussiger Duft. Haselnüsse, Zimt und Frucht. Antrunk überrascht mit Lakritz Noten. Dazu Malz und Nüsse. Recht herb. Im Abgang bittere Kräuteraromen. Rote Johannisbeere im Finish. Das Bier könnte ich mir auch in einem alten englischen Pub vom Fass vorstellen. Ziemlich orginell.

Bottle from Slijterij Groningen, a rather old bottle unfortunately. Chewy malty caramel aroma with toffee, biscuit, touch of fruits and hoppy notes which I imagine are more intense in a fresh sample. Flavour is medium sweet and mildly bitter. Body is medium. Age has turned this into a malt-bomb.

Poured golden color with a thin white head. 
Fruity, malty aroma, some biscuity notes. 
Flavor has similar things, biscuit, dark fruits. Hoppy, bitter finish, but feels old.

(Bottle, 0.355 l - BB 18.02.2017, at Kaunis Kampela, 20161118) The beer poured mahogany coloured and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had  fruitiness, caramel and biscuits. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were fruitiness, sweetness, biscuits, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was hoppy and bitter. A bit weak hoppy pale ale.
On tap. Copper with white head. Malt and pine hoppy aroma. Sweet caramel flavour with medium hoppy finish
Leicht trübes Bernstein mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Malzig, etwas Karamell, leicht fruchtig, Zitrusfrüchte, Orangen.

Bottle 35,5cl
@ LaBIRRAtorium, Madrid, Spain.
A: Hazy amber.
T: Malt, caramel, citrusy, hoppy.

Slightly hazy amber color with beige head. Aroma has grapefruit and resiny hops. Taste starts with grapefruit and orange, followed by an underlying malt sweetness and finishes with medium to intense piney hop bitterness. Light body but the mouthfeel is quite smooth. Really good overall. Classic, well made pale ale with high drinkability.
Hazy, dark amber beer. Limited carbonation. Light sour but full mouthfeel. Soft finish. Bitter aftertaste. Not bad at all.
Soberbia! Cobriza. Maltosa, presentes caramelo y frutos secos. Bastante cuerpo y ligeramente amarga
33cl bottle from cervezalandia. Dark cooper. Thin white head. Light sweetness, medium bitterness. Aroma is herbs, hops, malt, caramel.
Pours a clear golden amber with an off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, caramel, pine and hops. Taste is medium sweet leading to a hoppy finish.
355 ml bottle. Hazy dark orange colour with stable head off. Aroma of citrus fruits. Taste is hoppy with oranges, grapefruits, malty, huge bitter aftertaste.Moderate carbonation.
Bottle. Lively upon opening with quite a large head. Rather fruity with citrus floating around. More complex than I expected. Quite pleasant and easy to drink.

355 ml bottle. Hazy orange-brown capped with a sudsy off-white head. Orange, dark bread, caramel, flowers, pepper and marmalade in the nose. Smooth body delivers rich malt at first, zipped up by orange zest and pepper. Lingering finish with a slightly sweet aftertaste. Nice English style pale.

Medium head misty amber pour strong carbonation aromas citrus caramel the flavours caramel floral peach mild bitter earthy grain citrus strong tastes the finish good earthy notes hops grain notes very likeable ale

355mL bottle from Camperdown Cellars, Sydney
Deep golden body, firm white head.
Lovely nose of caramel, biscuity malt with spicy, slightly piney hops.
Smooth body, creamy sort of carbonation, full bodied.
Geared towards maltiness here - biscuity, toasty, slightly nutty with spicy hops delivering a moderate bitterness & nice finish.
Rather enjoyed this!
Bottle. Copper color. Aroma of malt, caramel and grass. Flavor of buttery caramel, malt and some faint bitter grassy hops. Its a bit old, but still allright.

33cl bottle at home. Hazy dark orange with a medium white soapy head. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Medium bitterness with subtle fruity tones. Citrus, pine, caramel, tropical fruits and some herbs. Very nice refreshing pale ale.

Dark amber, hazy, with a one finger high head. 

Nose: Nothing to write home about... Dried fruit, toffee, caramel malt, dark syrup and pine. 
Taste: Dried fruit, resin, grass, malt, a bit of citrus and some bread. 
Mouth: Medium body and carbonation. Prettyy easy drinking. A light bitterness. 

I think this is a great "dinnerbeer" because it doesenr run the show. It sits quiet in the back. 
To just drink and fell a great beer... Choose another beer, but to a diner with friends - Great!

BB 28/10/15. Poured a hazy coppery amber colour with a 5mm off-white foamy head that retained OK and laced OK. Carbonation very high and fine. Lots of yeast particles settling out. Aroma of pale malt, a hint of pine, a hint of yeast and possible grapefruit/citrus. Taste of moderately sweet malts with a moderate grapefruit bitterness. Light body. Crisp, clean, smooth, slightly dry and malty with a slightly soft bitterness on the finish. OK.

Bottle: Hazy, light amber coloured, stable and lacy off-white head; distinctive herbal-hoppy nose plus some x-mas spices(?), supported by a little bit of caramel and a tinge of vanilla in the background; dry bitter flavour with a very faint sweetness, astonishingly light bodied; lingering dry bitter-herbal finish, traces of cough-syrup included. Surely good, but IMHO a bit uniforme
Tap at Cosmic Comic Cafe. Caramel, bread, grass and fruits. Mild citrus. Mild to moderate sweetness and moderate bitterness. Bitter and somewhat dry finish.

Bottle from Archive Beer boutique 211015. This is an IPA that reminds me why I started drinking craft beer way back when - an old school IPA - no fuss, no bother, just straight up full flavour and aroma.

L:
-pours a slightly hazy amber-red with a medium to big, frothy, beige head
-lots of particles visible
-low to medium carbonation visible
S:
-earthy,caramel,toffee,grapefruit,pin bitterniss for the style
F:
-medium carbonation
-light to medium body
O:
-Probably to hoppy for a true-to-style English PA, but still very good

Aroma is malty with a pretty apparent bread character. Slightly floral. Sweet and caramelly taste with toffee at first, but then the hops grows on you from underneath with a low and earthy aura with an almost spicey bitterness. Solid.

Tap at the Porterhouse, badged as 5.6%,, brown with a red tinge and a lasting tight white head, faint biscuit and grapefruit nose with a slightly metallic blackberry tang, earthy malt with a citrusy dry-bitterness, a bit acrid in the finish.

355ml bottle from Bottle Bank, Falmouth. About a month out of date. Pours hazy amber with good off-white head. Malty aroma with some light fruit. Taste is a pretty easy-going pale, some mild fruits, nice moderately sweet malts, reserved bitter tones. Decent US bitter.

Draft at Beer Temple. Pours hazy amber brown with a medium cream head. Aroma of toffee, caramel malt, light fruits, orange peel and toast. Flavour is light moderate sweet and moderate bitter. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Pours clear coppery amber with a thick and frothy buff head. Malty aroma has hoppy and yeasty notes as co-stars. Refreshing flavor is mainly malty, with plenty of hops and fruity and yeasty hints. Texture has slightly thin body and so-so fizz. Still, catch a taste of these shoals.

Draught @ Cockney Pub, Aarhus. Pours slight hazy light brown with a offwhite head. Aroma of malt, grass, light fruity hops. Flavor is malt, little bread, grass, fruity hops, peach, mild citrus. Medium body, soft carbonation, light bitter finish. 030915
From the very old notes, hence this is not a real rating, but more just a mark to myself that I have tried this at one point. OK fruity pale ale with a bit watery body.
Very good stuff. Great complexity and balance between sweetness, acidity and bitterness.

Pours a deep copper color with a decent white head with laces and lingers a bit......aroma is citrus, pine, bread, sweet malt......taste is very clean, nice mouthfeel, citrus, bread, slight touch of pine, with bitterness in the back end. Quite nice.
bottle from Bierpost. Golden with a white head. Malty start, pleasantly fruity with citrus fruit - but not ans intensive as ecxpected. Best bitter from the US of A.

Bottle from Rudat, Dortmund. The beer starts fresh and malty. Hints of sourness with a subtle hoppy floralness. Nice fresh and easy to drink, but this subtle sourness with hints of cardboard doesnt fit too well. Probably my bottle is too old (best before is July 2015). But not bad at all. Fruity-fresh hints, nice bitter ending with a subtle ground sweetness.
Above average pale. Medium hops. Small amounts of citrus. Better on tap than the bottle.
Ámbar limpio y espuma marfil. Aromas cítricos y especiados, malta de fondo. Cuerpo medio-bajo, inicio maltoso, con sabor intenso de pino, cítrico y final de amargor resinoso

Bottle, 23 Club , Liverpool. Bottle. Copper pour with a skinny white head. Beak had some fragrant citrus hop and sweet malt present. Some decent enough hop emerged in the flavour married with some fruit and earth notes. Dried out towards the end. Pleasingly drinkable.

Bottle from Damian Beer and Ale. Aroma mostly hoppy, resiny, zesty citrusy, grapefruit, orange. Biscuity. Hazy amber colour, rather small head. Very nicely balanced in taste. Rather high carbonation lends it a crisp refreshing quality, assertive hops with citrusy resiny flavours is complemented sufficiently by biscuity malty background. Very good.
Pours a brown from a bottle. Smells of brown sugar, flavor has none of that, floral hoppiness is up front with a nice malty roundness. Good beer.

Bottle from Harvest Market, Bedford NH. Aroma is bready roasted malts, some yeasty dough and basement. Appearance is hazy amber brown with thin foamy white head with fair retention, nice lacing, nice sparkle. Taste is moderately sweet malt balanced with light bitter and hint of fruit. Palate is medium bodied with slightly slick texture, average carbonation to support the beer and an abrupt, dry finish. Overall, a rich but highly drinkable beer, without huge complexity.
12 oz. Bottle poured into round glass from craft 12 pack. Quite nice and drinkable. Great hop note.
Very nice beer, very refreshing taste, full flavour. Very good and sustained head.
Brassy amber with nice head. Smells like iced tea. Again, the hop flavor is of iced tea, which is complemented by an easy malting and a slight tannic bitterness. Very ESB-like.
Bottle. Pour is amber with a frothyhead, aroma is fruity. Taste is light fruity, resin, gentle bitterness. Good
Bottle from Beer Gonzo, Coventry. Spicy earthy aroma, some caramel and citrus in there. Taste is malty, with a touch of apricot and citrus. Slightly spicy finish. Tasty

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, best before 9/3/2015. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy deep orange/amber color with a 2 finger dense and fluffy light khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of grapefruit, apricot, lemon/orange zest, pear, apple, light pine, caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus/fruity hops and moderate bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of grapefruit, apricot, lemon/orange zest, pear, apple, pine, caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Moderate amount of piney/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, apricot, lemon/orange zest, pear, apple, pine, caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice compelxity, robustness, and balance of citrus/fruity hops and moderate bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balace and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, fairly crisp/sticky, and lightly creamy mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice American pale ale. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/fruity hops and moderate bready malt flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A very enjoyable offering.
Pours a clear amber, med off white head. Aroma is tangerine, grain, wheat, light Belgian yeast hint, grassy hop. Flavor is earthy bitter hops and malt, light sweet.
Tap at beertemple, amsterdam. Copper color, white head. Aroma has malts and hops, some fruits. Smooth hoppy taste, malts.
Bottle - I found this Pale Ale to be rather boring. No distinguishing characteristics that would make it worth while to drink again. Good amounts hops but still rather boring.

Oops, NH rate #100. Crazy, but This is so readily available I never got around to rating it. Taster at the source. Pours medium brown with a beige head. Aroma is multigrain bread, light floral. Flavor follows, caramel, multigrain bread, floral, grassy hop bitterness.

On tap @ Beer Temple, sample size glass. Clear amber color with a big, white to off white head like whipped cream, good retention and sticking to the glass. Aromas: resinous, light fruit, also a bit herbal. Flavor is moderate bitter, slightly earthy, with light fruity sourness. Light bodied. Long bitter finish.
Bottle from Beer Gonzo, Coventry. Hazy Amber colour, foamy white head. Aroma is fruity hops, but nice and delicate. Taste fruity hops as well with a bitter sweet taste.
Medium amber with an off white head. Aroma of sweet berries and nuts. Light to medium body, flavour is medium sweet, moderately bitter.
A very nice pale ale. Pours darker than most, thin head. Good flavor, well balanced between malts and hops.

Cerveza de color Rojizo Ámbar con una buena espuma blanca, densa y perdurable.
Tiene un aroma floral y herbal con notas de naranjas, malta y caramelo.
El sabor es de lúpulo amargo y un final seco y agradable. De cuerpo medio, notas de caramelo, cítricos y galletas. Cerveza refrescante, sabrosa y bastante agradable.

Shared bottle. Pours is ligth amber with thick white head. Aroma is fruity, lime, tangerine, pine, resin, cinnamon and some peach, bit spicy. Taste is medium bitter, fruity with some citruses, tangerine, lime and orange peel. Fresh one.

From 0,355l bottle, BBD: 03/ Sep/ 15. Pours clear amber liquid, medium frothy tan head, Aroma: fruity - tangerine, litchi, caramel, malty, bready, licorice, Taste: medium sweet, medium bitter, light sour, caramel, fruity, well balanced, Palate: medium body, oily texture, average carbonation, long malty bitter finish, Overall: very good, very well balanced, very drinkable, nice bready caramel body, enjoyed.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2015 (Smuttynose Shoals Pale Ale) Bottle 355 ml at home, served into a teku glass.
Deep copper orange colour on the body, crystal clear. Three full fingers of thick, off-white head on top, with great retention, leaving medium lacing around the glass.
Sweet malty aroma, light caramel, some red and dark fruits, nice hoppy touches too.
Taste has also malts, light caramel, toffee, hoppy notes. Nicely bitter finish and aftertaste, with a long duration as well.
Medium body, carbonation on good levels.
Nothing mind-blowing but still drinkable and honest beer.

Clear amber color with medium beige head. Aroma is malty but very weak, some hop presence, but malts and caramel dominates it. Taste is much better, malty, caramely, with citrus and some pine. Smooth finish with slightly bitterness.

Na, das war eine recht malzige Angelegenheit, die sich jedoch mit einer netten Portion Stroh und und Gras dennoch in die richtige Richtung bewegt. Daneben noch der richtige Einsatz von Hopfen und ein klein wenig Zitrone. Klassisch, aber ebenso klasse.
From tap at Taphouse , Copenhagen. Clear golden colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of hops, citrus, grass, spice, malt an caramel.

Bottle from Rudat in Dortmund. The beer has got a clear amber-red colour with a low head and medium body. Aroma of hops and fruits. Taste of hops, malt, barley, vanilla, caramel and flowers. Hints of oranges and bread. Easy and smooth to drink, very quaffable. Good one.

330ml bottle. Aroma is light mango, light floral. Appearance is clear golden with a huge white to brown-ish foam. Taste is bitter and light sweet. Watery, medium carbonation. Light dryness, stays bitter. Good.
On tap. @El Lúpulo Feroz, Oviedo 11/04/2015. Color ambar, Aromas dulces, maltosos, Sabor a caramelo. Cuerpo medio, Amargor ligero.

350ml bottle. Clear, copper-ish amber colour with small to average, frothy to creamy, fairly lasting, minimally lacing, off-white head. Generally cautious aroma has hints of mint and a bready, doughy malty touch. Taste delivers fully integrated, mild notes of malts and hops; slightly doughy, bready, caramel malty with subtle sweetness on one hand, bitter hoppy, minimally citrusy, with a touch of gooseberry on the other - additionally a spicy-herbal yeasty touch between aniseed and basil. Super soft, smooth palate, gentle but insistent carbonation.
On tap @ BierCaB, Barcelona. Pours copper with an offwhite creamy head. Aroma of caramel, dark bread, some fruitiness. Medium bodied, bitter finish.
Floral aroma. Pours a copperish-red color. Easy drinking, non-descript front end, and middle. The finish is a moderate bitter.
Bottle from Beermerchants. Pours clear dark golden with a big creamy white head. Aroma of pale malts, bread and spicy hops.Taste is moderate sweet, with a strong herbal and spicy bitter finish.
Orange, rötlich. Grapefruit in der Nase, sehr präsente Malznoten, etwas Karamell. Gut.
355ml bottle. Pours hazy, a reddish copper colour with foamy white head. Slight bread aroma, taste is complex with initial fruit, turning sour, then leaving a bitter, bread aftertaste. Good stuff

On tap at Memphis, Surprised I havent ticked this before. Pours Amber brown color with medium off white head. Notes of sweet and lightly sticky malt, nice bitter pine hops, and ashy bready grains. Some good lacing on glass. Balanced but not my kind of pale ale. Prefer them golden or yellow with more citrus but can appreciate this brew.
Bottle - hazy amber with thick off-white head. Malty, bready hoppy aroma. Same in the taste, some chalk, medium mouthfeel, low carbonation. Decent stuff.

(bottle, 35.5cl, 5.4% abv) Clear, deep golden to copper colour with a medium-sized and slightly tanned foamy head. Mildly biscuity malty aroma with hints of toffee, accompanied by minty, peppery and slightly resiny hops. Bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Slightly bready and delicately toasted malty taste with notes of caramel/toffee and shades of chocolate far in the background, backed by drying spicy hops, lingering into the bitter-sweet finish with balancing malt character. Fine stuff. 28.I.15

A favorite of mine, pours copper with white head and nice lacing. Aromas of pine and citrus - my kind of hop varieties for sure. Flavor carries the initial hop bite quickly smoothed with a delicious maltiness that keeps me coming back for more. one of my favorite summer sessions.
Pours dark copper with zero head. Malty aroma. Very malty backbone. Delicious beer, well worth it.
Quite English alright with a very bready malt and a hint of floral aroma against the more American piney bitterness of the hops. Nice blend.

Una english pale ale sopra gli standard. Di colore ambrato, molto limpido, con lievi riflessi ramati, si presenta con una schiuma molto fine bianca, non abbondante e nemmeno troppo persistente. allolfatto viene fuori con predominanza assoluta la nota di uva, seguita da tè nero e lievi sentori di carruba. Molto fruttata comunque. Al palato il corpo molto ben equilibrato e consistente sprigiona note maltate e caramellate, senza altri sentori. Al palato e nel retrogusto prevalgono note erbacee, quasi terrose, che danno un buon amaro e una lunga persistenza che però non infastidisce il sorso che risulta molto secco. Di buona beveribilità complessiva.
nice balance malt/hop aroma. amber in color with a decent head. taste is full bodies, malty upfront with a strong hop finish

0,355 l bottle from Rudat, 5.4 % abv, best before 7/6/2015. Clear, amber with a big, frothy, slowly diminishing, tan head. Light floral or citrusy aroma with hints of nuts. Sweetish taste of nuts, roasted malts and toffee. Short, slightly bitter finish. Thin to medium body, oily mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Pleasant beer with high sessionability. Very taste, rather mild and well-balanced.
Caña en el lúpulo en 20-02-2015 pale ale con sabores amargos y toques algo tostados no muy intensos. Normal

In bottiglia. Colore ramato, schiuma fine e poco persistente, limpida. Aroma intenso di caramello e toffee che aumenta allo scaldarsi della birra. Ben bilanciato da una luppolatura erbacea e terrosa. Al palato ritroviamo il caramello dominanta con la luppolatura che bilancia bene la dolcezza senza però donare freschezza alla birra. Probabilmente un pò stanca, con luppoli che ne risentono.
Pours a coppery orange. Lots of lacing. Molasses and honey on the nose. Full bodied. Some sweetness from the malts, toffee, and bitter hops. A flavorful pale ale. Im a fan.
Tap at Beer Hunters. Clear deep amber color, steady off-white head. Toffee pale malty aroma. Light-bodied to medium-bodied. Pale malty, toffee. Maybe better on the other side of the bond.

bottle @ Jungle Jims / Eastgate OH --- Clear deep amber color, good beige head that drops, after a minute or two, to a solid cover, bands of lace. Taste is malt with a little peach (or is it apricot?) that flaunts hops on the swallow, only to have malt reassert itself on a drifting, long finish. But, wait, at the tail end bitter hops once again sweep all else away. A marvelous brew for 5%, tasty, balanced, intriguing,...a winner.
Copper pour with a decent white head. Caramel, dark fruit, pine, leafy. Decent carbonation and zesty. At 5% its a decent session beer. Not a world beater.

pours copper with thick white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of malt and citrus. flavor is citrus, resin and caramel malts. Hops are much more pronounced in the flavor than the aroma. Medium body with a bitter resinous finish.
On tap at Biercab. Copper colour with white head. Malt, caramel and herbal aroma. Sweet, matl, caramel, herbal, earthy and hoppy taste. Medium body.

Cervesa on predominen les maltes però amb un toc a llúpol final, molt equilibrada.
Cerveza donde predominan las maltas pero con un toque a lúpulo final, muy equilibrada.
Bottle pale ale bel ambrato quasi limpida buona schiuma piuttosto persistente caramello lieve resinoso buona luppolatura lieve nota agrumata floreale terroso discreto corpo
Bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. Hazy amber coloured with caramel, burnt toffee and roasted malt flavours followed by a slight chocolate, nutty and bitter creamy finish.

Clear, lively copper beer with a frothy head and an aroma of fruit and burnt caramel. Flavour is slightly more bitter, with the fruit more prominent but the toasty malt coming through slightly stronger.
Copper colour, light coloured head. Nice smooth palate, medium bodied, malty toasty flavour.
Dark amber/cider color; Medium body; Aroma of malt, hops, & some caramel; Flavor of malt, pine hops, and citrus; Finish is bitter; Nicely balanced; Pretty good.
Draft sampler pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, pine and citrus. Taste is malts and citrus.
Keg anchorage Sheffield. Amber thin head. Aroma us fruity. Taste is fruity good malts nice dry hoppy bitterness well balanced. Medium body. Good stuff.

Bottle. Pours a deep copper-orange with a high, light tan, lacy, medium-grained blown-insulation head. Nose is floral, apricot, rosemary, and biscuity. Toffee-orange sweetness on the front of the tongue, then with a herbal hops kick on the mid-palate; carbonation is light, with more treacly sweetness at the back of the mouth. Finish is long, sweet, and clean. Quite nice, and easy to drink.

Nose is yeast, peach, grain. Taste is cereal, biscuit, light bitterness malt. 

Incredibly forgettable bitter. I seem to have a drink with a completely different taste profile to some of the other reviews. Not exporting well?
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; cloudy dark chestnut brown pour with a thin beige head, malt and pine aroma, taste has caramel, dark fruit, lightly toasted bread, pine, citrus, creamy mouthfeel.
12oz bottle from Valhallas Goat. Medium reddish orange brown. Grain aroma. Dry caramel flavour. Bitter aftertaste. More a light amber ale than a pale ale.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours reddish brown with a off white head. Taste citrus, Carmel, bitter. I thought this was good. I could drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a reddish brown with a frothy, white head. Nose is rather hoppy, some good grapefruit notes and a hint of grass. Taste is moderately bitter and refreshing. Finish is long and malty. Medium body, lively carbonation. Tasty brew!
Hazy amber colour. Sweet, malty, caramel, citrus and pine hop character, some bitterness at the end

Bottle from Cornelius. Hazy chestnut brown body with a thick off-white head. Light lacing. Aroma of leafy earthiness, dirt, tea and a minty finish. Flavour of grassy bitterness, caramel and lightly roasted malt. Thin body with a watery, slightly oily mouthfeel. Soft fizz. Crisp and simple. Tastes like a classic Bitter.
Bottle from StarmoreBoss, Sheffield. Hazy, copper colour. Glossy, bubbly, off white head. Blimey. What happened? Theres some citric bitterness in there. Some sweet malt. Thats about it, really.
Bottle at home from mchughs. Pours ruby red with white head. Pot pouri, honey, nose. Caramel chewy flavour, some floral notes, mild bitterness. Short dry finish. Nice
Bottle. Light orange brown with a thin head. Aroma is piney resin. Flavour is biscuity malt, spicy, dry bitter hop finish. Dry bitter palate.

355ml bottle from Appellation Wines - cheers Ash! Pours clear amber with a decent off-white head. Aromas are funky yeast, light orange, sherbet. Agree is smells a bit off! Taste brings more citrus, bitter.Creamy texture, medium body. Not convinced.

355ml bottle from Appellation Wines.
Appearance - golden amber with a nice head. 
Nose - a bit of funky farmyard. Smells a bit off.
Taste - orange and grapefruit 
Palate - medium bodied with a creamy yet tangy texture and a long dry finish.
Overall - the nose was a real off-put but it improved after that.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a mug. It came as part of a mix pack for $15.99 ($1.33 per bottle or $0.11 per ounce). 

Appearance: Surprisingly dark brown with a honey glow. Hazy with carbonation initially present. Pours to a small, white, foamy head which retains and laces well.

Smell: Slightly fruity scent, but distinctly malty. A hint of hops. 

Taste: Not too many American breweries do an English-style pale ale, and those that do dont tend to do them too well. While Smuttynose Shoals Pale Ale may not be an exact authentic replica of a British brew, its most definitely not American, either. The malts are actually the star of the show, here, though theres still plenty of hop character you expect in a pale ale.

Up front I notice a sweet malt flavor with notes of toast, muffins and orange marmalade. The hops are present as well, but dont reveal themselves until the finish. The beer has a consistent slightly dry bitterness throughout, which really complements the darker malt flavor. Perhaps a hint of citrus from the hops can be detected, which is nice. A mild bitter bite as it goes down keeps the palette well-balanced and interesting. Its not Fullers, but itll do.

Drinkability: The pale ale is supposed to be overtly drinkable, especially compared to the IPA, and Smuttynose Shoals Pale Ale definitely succeeds in this aspect. The mouthfeel is perfectly medium all around. Robust enough flavor to keep it interesting, but still crisp and smooth to make it easy to quaff down. This beer weighs in at 5.6% ABV, which seems just about right (maybe a tad high). A little too big to session, but strong enough to enjoy as a standalone serving.

Fruity notes in the background. Bitter liquorice finish on a malty background and a lingering tartness. A really nice beer  I liked the hard candy bit. 19.02.11.
Pours amber with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, pine and grapefruit. Flavour is caramel, medium bitter, pine, citrus, peach and grapefruit.

Shoals Pale Ale pours a deep orange amber.  The head was almost non-existent.  The aroma is bready and sweet and the taste is mild with a malty presence.  It finishes clean and seems well-balanced.  Could be a great session beer!
UPDATED: FEB 21, 2012 Very excellent India Pale Ale. I wish I could get this beer more often because I would buy it more often.
Pours a nice copper color with a thin white head. Citrus and cardboard aroma. Nice body, slightly bready, touch of caramel sweetness and a big bitter hop bite. Decent brew.

DARK AMBER ALE WITH A SWEET INTERESTING CINNAMON AROMA AND THIN WHITE HEAD.  SEEMS TO BE AN ABUNDANCE OF LIGHT FLAVORS IN THIS ONE THAT ARE ALL BALANCE VERY WELL CARAMEL BREAD LIKE MALTS WITH SWEET CINNAMON HOPS, AGAIN THESE FLAVORS ARE FAINT YET STILL  APPARENT. THIS IS A VERY NICE LIGHTER BEER.

Botella en el bar Mikkeller. Hazy amber colour with a white ish head, ok lacing. Sweet caramel malty aroma. Ok mouthfeel. The flavour is sweet with caramel and hops, some eyast. Old hoppy sweet brew like.... not so much bitterness.

hazy copper, thin but lasting white head,  sticky medium-full body, bubbly high carbonation.

aroma: minerality, pungent leafy hops, bready sweet pale malt, and a bit of yeast esters.

taste: strong minerality, lots of herbal leafy hops with a touch of grapefruit rind, grainy pale and amber malts, a slight woody note as it warms, and a lingering vegetal leafy bitterness between each drink.
Bottle 12oz: An copper coloured New Hampshirean Pale Ale with an quite sublime hoppy tangy manderine-like taste, this is an very good ale with an strange looking label.

From the 12oz bottle - a nice copper pour with minimal head and almost no lacing. A bit of floaties in the pub glass. I get mustard pretzel bread on the nose. The flavor is fairly balanced with woody notes and bitter herbs followed by some sweet, almost chocolate cake undertones. Finishes with a dry mouthfeel. Definitely fits the English style.
12 oz. bottle in a snifter.  Clear golden pour with medium head.  Ok for a pale ale.  Not too hoppy, but fairly flavorful.  Not a big fan.
Bottle @ Odense tasting. Ruby body with a small offwhite head. Aroma is light hops, caramel and fruit. Flavor is hops, fruit, grape fruit. Bitter end. Waterish.
Bottle. Low lasting white fluffy head. hazy amber body. Malty fruity grassy aroma. Relativelhy bitter grassy fruity flavor with low carbonation and a long bitter aftertaste.
Bottle @ MikkellerBar. Hazy orange/amber with big off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit and not a much hops as I had expected.
Amber with a small white head. Aroma of fruity hope, tangerine and mango, with some toffee malt notes. Dry and well balanced flavour of malt and fruity hops. Nice and bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours a nice hazy copper color with a frothy beige head. Aroma is of citric and piney hops along with some caramel and sweet matliness. The flavor is up front slightly hoppy with flavors of citrus and pine, then you get some more malty notes of caramel, toffee and some breadiness. The body is medium with a crisp mouthfeel. Overall a solid Pale Ale, that taste like a combination of an American Pale Ale hopwise and an English one maltwise.

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, Jan 2011. Pours clear amber copper with a small lasting white head. Nose is citrus and grapefruit. Dry and hoppy flavor with notes of peach and grapefruit. Medium bodied. Crisp and dry. Nice.

Smuttynose Shoals Pale Ale
Bottle 35,5 cl. Pours amber with a slight haze and a rough off-white head. Spicy hoppy nose. Rather light body, dry fruitiness with a dry hopping. The hops are not distinctly American, no citrus or peach. Dunno, but Id call this an English Pale Ale. The finish is bitter though. 160111
6/3/7/3/13

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar.
Clear orange red coloured with a small off-white head.
Fruity aroma of caramel, hops and pine needles.
Fruity flavour of caramel, hops and pine needles.
Hoppy finish.
12 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is spiced and caramelish malty. Fruity, sweet and slight floral hoppy flavoured. Sweet and fruity finish.
clear brown, smooth white head.nutty, malty, flowey aroma. Flavor is flowery hoppy, mild, watery, refreshing.
Bottle from Bierkoning. Amber body with big head. Floral sweet and citrus nose. Taste is malts and pines. Watery but pretty good.

Flaske: Ravfarvet let diset øl med et flot skumhoved. Duften er let blomstret humlet. Ikke typisk amerikansk. Let bitterhed og stor maltsødme gør det næsten til en amber, men igen er humlingen fantastisk godt balanceret og gør øllen særdeles drikbar.

Bottle. Pours clear amber with a creamy off white head. The aroma is fruity hoppy with notes of citrus, oranges, grass, spices and caramel. The flavour is crispy pine, citrus and light grape fruit. Quite bitter finish. Medium bodied.

Bottle at home. Pours a clear amber with a tanned head. Smells of caramel malts with spicy hints. Dry with aromas of cereals, hops and caramel malts. Medium bodied. Medium to soft carbonation. Dry finish with some hops aromas.
12 oz bottle. New Years beer, the others I had rated. Amber pour with a large, creamy off-white head. Nose of sweet malt, toffee, caramel, and florals. Malty taste with subtle fruity tones. Not bad.

Hazy amber body with a small, finely bubbled off white head that lasts and leaves great lacing. Slightly nutty, toasty aroma with dough and light hops. Caramel and biscuit malts and nuts upfront, with sharp, clean bitterness to finish. Not a lot of hop flavor for the amount of bitterness, but still very enjoyable. Full body with busy carbonation. Decent, but not great.

Deep amber body with a beautiful off-white head that clings nicely to the glass.  Complex and inviting aroma.  Caramel, berries, citrus, and a hint of pine.  Smooth, creamy palate with a decent bite of carbonation at the back.  The flavor takes the great aroma and steps it up a notch.  Sweet entry with caramel and bread coming to mind.  The brew finishes appropriately bitter with a grapefruit and pine bite.

Pours an ever so lightly hazy old copper with a 2 finger, creamy, off white head that has great retention nad leaves nice lacing. Aroma is of toast, light caramel, pale malt, light nutty notes, hardwood bark, underripe berries and citrus. Flavor is nutty malt, caramel, toast, raw grain, hints of citrus, grass and mineral notes, and a touch of pine near the finish. Palate is light bodied and slightly (pleasantly) dry throughout, with a medium, sharp carbonation. This is a very enjoyable EPA, not a style that I generally find myself being to fond of.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy brown with a medium white head. Aromas of pine, some sitruc and caramel. Flavors of bready malt and pine with a nice hoppy finish. A solid pale ale.
12 oz bottle on holiday. The first blah Smuttynose Ive had. Its sufficiently hoppy for a modern American pale ale, but tastes fairly one-note. Not bad, but not good either.

On tap at Portsmouth brewpub. Pours out a amber/brownish topped with a white head. Aroma was of light citrus hops and bread malts. Taste was more of the light citrus hops lemon, sweet bread, and finishes with a bitter end.
Pretty good pale ale.   Fairly well hopped, especially on the nose.  Flavor is grapefruit, bread and pine.  I like this much better than the Mirror Pond I just had.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Duvel tulip. Best before February 2011 notched on label.

Appearance: Pours a dark caramel color with a very small 1/4 finger white head. Nice lacing.

Smell: Bready malt with light hints of citrus and pine. Fairly earthy. Not as hoppy as I would have liked.

Taste: Lemon zest up front followed by bready malts and a hint of sweet citrus in the middle then ending with pine and grapefruit at the finish. Aftertaste is bitter with just a hint of earthiness. Much hoppier flavor than the aroma indicated. Surprisingly well-balanced.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. You could down a few of these without much trouble.

Overall: Pretty good beer overall. While not the best pale ale out there, its worth a shot.

Finally in Chicago!  Pours reddish amber pour with nice white head.  Aroma of citrus, cherries, fruit cocktail, some toffee and caramel.  Strong bitter flavor with some fruit, some caramel notes.  Bready, assertively grapefruit.  Pretty nice bitterness.  Mouthfeel nice for a pale.  Pretty good ale.

Bottle to chilled pint glass.  Pours a  brown / yellow / amber color.  Hazy, with sparse head, but decent lacing.  Smells lightly of hops.  Straight up Pale Ale flavor to me.  Piney / citrus flavors of the hops dominant.  Clean and crisp finish with just  a touch of malts.  Nice
Pale ale is not pale. Pours a cloudy medium orange brown and gets a nice hard. Perfect from bottle to pint. Slightly nutty in aroma and flavor also with pine. Not bad.

Bottle: Pours a dark copper, slightly cloudy color - nice white head with tiny bubbles, i suppose. The head has a frothy character that is interesting - Aromas are earthy and malty - Flavors are distinctly different, however. Bread and Cookies mesh with a heavy hop bitterness on this brew. It is heavier than expected - and no I get zero "tangy fruit" at the start like the description states - I think this is my first brew in the English Pale Ale category; With that said, I think this one is fantastic for what it is.

Pours dark amber.  Aroma is kind of like stale hops...not that great.  Taste is great, hops bitterness with a bit of malt in the background.  The bitterness and malt  remains in the aftertaste.  Medium carbonation.   A pale ale that an IPA fan will enjoy.  Easy drinking.  Good, but I probably wont seek it out again.

Pours clear deep copper with tan head. The modest aroma emits some pine hops, mild graininess, floral hops and some spicy hops too. The taste is a bitter hoppy mix of pine, spicy and floral hops to go along with a thin layer of sweet malts underneath. It stays pretty bitter with hops running right into the after taste. Nice stuff with plenty of hops for a Pale.

12pz bottle. Pours deep copper witha thick off white head. Aroma is exactly what a good pale ale should be. A touch citric, a touch piney with some strong caramel and grainy malts. Flavor starts a touch citric and sweet caramel. Picks up a gentle hop bite with some pine bitterness towards the finish. Medium body and a softer carbonation. Really refreshing and easy drinking pale ale

Dark red-amber with good, foamy, tan head / Lightly sweet nose of sour malt and caramel / Light to medium body, a touch watery, with good balance and bitter finish / Flavors of toast and dry hops, with a hint of caramel / Not enough experience with English pales to fairly judge - would guess an above average example.

12 oz bottle.  Pours copper (somewhat on a darker side of Pale ales) with a lasting off-white head.  Aroma and flavor are dominated by citrus, piney hops.  Some sweet malt in the background.  Light to medium, tangy body. Long, dry, bitter finish.  Nothing is wrong with this brew, but personally, I prefer a little more balance in my Pale Ales.

A bit shocked at the rating here.  I found this to be a very boring pale with hardly any genuine or unique hop or malt character.  A sort of chemical, off putting bitterness.  Maybe I just had a bad bottle, but I wont be trying this one again to find out.
Nice copper color but malt overshadows hoppiness.  Good balance overall but not spectacular.

Bottle. After the pour, a clear copper body with an aggressively fizzed white head that dissipates quickly. An earthy, grassy hop flavor with a bready malt note. This beer has a decently sized body. Great session.

Pours a nontransparent burnt orange.  Off white head with little lacing.  Based on the color I expected a stronger aroma.  Medium aroma...carmel and hops.  Taste is a great combo of hops, malts, citrus, and bitterness.  Overall one of my favorite Pales.
Pours way too dark, almost a pale brown, nose is pure caramel, taste is really grainy, burnt sugar, tons of bitterness, no hop flavor.

Presentation: It was poured into from a brown 12 oz bottle into a tall Pilsner glass. The label has a freshness date but no ABV%.

Appearance: From the pour I got a rich amber colored beer with a tall white head on top. The head has very good retention and excellent lacing. It leaves nice lace rings on the glass at each sip level. 

Smell: The aroma has an inviting mix of sweet bready and light caramel maltiness with solid citrus and herbal leafy spicy hops.

Taste/Palate: There is a good solid hop character with nice crisp citrus and spicy notes laid over a study foundation of bready malt that matches the bitterness from the hops. There is a touch of caramel sweetness in there as well. The finish is long and slow with a good balance of hops and malt. Its palate has a good medium to full body and a firm yet yielding texture. 

Notes: For me this is a well done Pale Ale.

Bottle.  Pours a clear orange amber with a white head.  Nose is sweet with citrus hops, a hint of caramel, some grass.  Light to medium body with mild citrus hops (less than suggested by the nose) and a big serving of medium malts with hints of nuts and caramel.  Fairly bitter throughout.  Finish is dry and bitter with a lingering nutty malt taste.

12oz bottled June 30, 2010.  Pours hazy burnt orange/copper/amber with a two finger light beige head that leaves some drippy rings of lacing but holds only a faint cap and ring.  Aroma is grassy, herbal, and floral hops, caramel malt and strong bready presence.  Moderate strength, but gets better as it warms.  Flavor is very similar to the nose, grassy, floral hops with some added citrus balanced against bready, caramel malt, finishes with a strong bitterness to balance against moderate sweetness from the malt.  Refreshing and very flavorful.  Medium bodied, medium (although occasionally prickly) carbonation.  Drinks very nicely.  Mmmmm this is some tasty stuff.  I generally like the less malty American-style Pale Ales, but this bad boy may sway me to the dark(er) side.  This is very hoppy too which is a plus for me, but not a surprise since it is coming from the brewer of my favorite IPA.

Pale ale moderate hop aroma.  Pale ale, gold appearance.  Fruit citrus and light in color.

Notes: On Cask at GBBF 10

Bottle from SuIIy, thanks! Pours a beautiful color of copper red. Poor clarity. Long lasting fluffly off-white head. A nice hint of fruity hops is dominated by biscuity goodness. Really full flavored beer, starts off strangely puckering when it first hits the mouth and immediately transitions to a fully rich malt flavor with a perfectly balanced and long aftertaste. Fifteen second after each sip, I can still enjoy a rich brown toasty bready maltiness. This is really good, and to this point probably my favorite example of an English pale.

Pours a dark amber with a thin tan head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is of nutty earthy malts with a bit of hops mixed in. Taste is earthy nutty malts but the sweetness is cut off by a strong hop bitter. This beer is good, a more hopped brown dog, but I may prefer the less bitter variety.

amber - light orange.  strong hop aromas - very pleasing.  Well-balanced hop profile on the tongue.  Probably the hoppiest pale ale I have ever had - probably closer to an IPA although Ive heard that the Smuttynose IPA has enough hops to blow your mind.
Bottle. Pours amber with a white head. Flavor is burnt malts, hops, some citrus. Theres a lot going on here and its well balanced but just a tad boring.

355mL courtesy of tastybeer. Pours a clear deep yellow to light orange with a medium off-white head with excellent sheety lacing. Aroma is lemon tea, biscuit, iron / metallic. Taste is malty, doughy, tea with cream, fairly rich cream of wheat, tinny bitterness. Decent.

Deep amber in color, clear and sparkling. A big one-inch head, white and foamy head that leaves thick lacing. Toasted malt, caramel, piney hops, and metalic aromas. Medium-bodied and pretty smooth on the palate. The flavor is lightly sweet with bread and caramel malt, balanced with piney dry bitterness and an unfortunate metalic finish. The appearance and palate are first rate, but the nose is a bit dull and the metalic aroma and flavor ruined the brew for me. Disappointing.

Citrus, pine, pear and maybe even strawberry all present in the aroma.  Enticing, but hazy, orange color with pillowy off-white head.  Slightly sweet with strong hop bitterness initially and as carbonation passes the malt comes to the forefront.  Much hoppier than a true English pale ale, even hoppier than many British IPAs.  But I like it anyhow.  Also light on esters in taste with a pretty clean fermentation profile.  Exceptional beer if not exactly to style.

I was expecting an American pale, but after pouring this nice dark copper beer with a small beige head and smelling the nicely balanced hop and malt aroma I am pretty happy with the purchase. The flavor is perfectly balanced, tartness from the hops slips into a nice caramel and sweet bread malt. One heck of a pale ale, hope the rest of the mix pack is this good.
Bottle from drowland.  Orange pour with a white head.  Aroma is sweet malts, a little roasted, and earthy.  Taste is very earthy, spicy, burned caramel, and bitter.

Bottle from Fratto via drowland.  Or is it from drowland via Fratto?  Oh hell. Clear bright orange color.  Small bubbles on the white head.  Sappy hops on the nose.  Some syrupy sweet notes. Heavy bitter hops with dry notes on the flavor.  Finishes pretty dry.

6/18/10.  12oz bottle into a pint glass.  Cloudy brownish pour with a nice off-white head that turns to a ring but sticks around.  The aroma is nice pale malt and a hint of hops.  The flavor packs a bitter wallop for a pale, which is refreshing.  Nice caramelly background in there as well.  Not bad.

Draft at a bar in Lake Winnipesaukee, NH.  Pours clear amber in color with a frothy white head.  Aroma is nice and hoppy, very citrusy with bready malt.  Flavor is mildly sweet with more hop flavor than bitterness.  Nice breadiness and caramel.  Medium-bodied with a fairly standard mouthfeel for the style.  A very enjoyable pale ale overall.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2010 aroma is light toast, beginnings of fruit, caramelized orange.  appearance is similar color to darkened sucrose made reference to in nose.  flavor is big balance of strong stand-up pine and excellent toast - but toasted malt goes the distance.  delectable!

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours a hazy chesnut brown with a thick, frothy beige head. Aroma of fresh bread, roasted malts, caramel, and nice hints of hops. Medium  bodied with a smooth, slightly bitter palate. Excellent pale ale.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2011 Bottle. My friend and I call this beer "Jennys house" because the label looks like Jennys childhood house in Forrest Gump. As a  beer, its about a good a pale as youre going to get. Kind of like a box of chocolates, only its golden with a nice white head.
Taste and nose of well balanced hop bitterness and malts. Rated 6/15/02
Bottle - I enjoyed the unfiltered appearance and very low carbonation.  Almost a cask appearance.  Lots of hops with a grapefruit and citrus flavor.  The second is a easy choice.

aroma is sweet caramel and mild bitter fruit and earth hops--toast and peaches. 
pours a clear amber with small offwhite frothy head.
flavor has medium bitterness and light sweetness, kinda watery.
light body, somewhat thin, lively carbonation, with decent bitter finish.
Tap at Murphys in Brookline, MA.  Deep, dark chestnut color, thin white head, medium lacing.  Aroma of subtle licorice and malt.  Taste has caramel, hops.  Simple, clean, refreshing.

Medium amber with a red hue glow. Aromas of sweet caramel and hops, mingled with slight floral fruity notes. Flavors of caramel undertoned by floral hops, slight grain. Bitter finish. Its just another pale easily forgotten by the next day. Good though.

Pours a clear burnt orange. Thin, foamy head. Snow white with minimal lacing. Aroma is fairly weak. Bready and some dark sugars. No hop nose at all. Lightly fruity at the onset. Very crisp. Slightly bitter finish with a strong malt backbone. Really decent flavor, although the aftertaste is a bit off. A little too sugary. Very crisp on the palate. Slightly stingy carbonation levels, but they do well for the style. Very solid session beer. Just a tad bit sugary, perhaps slightly under fermented. But overall, an enjoyable beer.

Pours a hazy amber with a white head. Aroma is of citrus hops and a bit of malt. Taste starts off with citrus hops, moves to a mild malt and finishes with a lingering bitterness. Palate is good, not too heavy with a bit of zing at the start. Overall, a decent beer that is very drinkable.

2007: Shiny light orange. Looks quite hazy. Head goes away but leaves a foamy top layer. Big-time carbonation. Thick lace 

Nice, sweet pale malt smell with a nice first wave of sweet citrus hops. Also a bit flowery. Malt has a little bite in the nose; gets sharper. 

Nice pale malt. The hops are an accent only. Has a combination of flowery and nutty. Has a roasted quality I didnt expect. Yeast shows up as it warms. Sweet/flowery at the end. 

Drya nd medium-bodied, and a tad ashy. Its a good pale. Malty, a little sharp. Dry, but also light and drinkable.

Draft sample at Portsmouth Brewery as part of a tasting rack the night before Kate Day 2010.  Pours a clear amber with a small off-white head.  Aroma of grassy hops, caramel malts, biscuit, and earthy notes.  Flavor is also grassy and earthy, with hop bitterness offset by toast and caramel malty sweetness.  Light-medium bodied, with gentle carbonation and a crisp finish.  Nice EPA.

12 ounce bottle.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours a hazy orange/amber color with a half inch off-white head.  Head retention and lacing are both pretty good.  Aroma is pine and citrusy hops, and some caramel malt.  Taste is much hoppier compared to the aroma.  The brew tastes similar to the aroma, like pine and citrusy hops and some grain/bready malt.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit slick and is well carbonated.  Drinkability is good, its enjoyable to drink and not a bad choice for an occasional session beer.  I only bought a single bottle of this, but Ill buy a six pack of this in the future.  I think its a good, sessionable APA.
Bottle.  Pours amber with nice white head.  Smell of mild hopy goodness.  Taste is the same with a smooth finish.  One that is easy drinkable.
great aroma and body round out this easy sessionable offering from smuttynose. one of my favorites.

This brew is dark golden in color with a thick, light caramel colored head.  It doesnt look like a pale ale.  Aroma is mainly of piny hops, with some malts.  Flavor is of hops, some earthiness, and malts.  Leaves a nice hoppy finish.  This one is tasty.
Bottle. Amber pour, white carbonation. Toasted pumpernickel bread, cookie, earthy and bitter hops. Nicely balanced. Medium body, balanced, easy. Solid session brew.
Thanks to Solan.  Amber color.  Aroma of caramel and nobel hops.  Flavor of grassy hops and burnt sugar.  Not a bad session brew.
Drank from a bottle out of the Smuttynose Mix pack.  A medium bodied, full finish pale ale.  goes down easy, smooth and clean.

My first Smuttynose beer.  On tap at Chappys in Dayton. 
English style pale ales arent my favorite by far, but this one is pretty nice.  Has a nice floral flavor with moderate bitterness.
Bottle, case.  Poured a clear, pale amber/copper with decent foam head.  Medium body, dry with some biscuit and hop notes.  Some hop bitterness in the finish.

The 12 oz bottle was via a trade with "The Wheelman" in New Hampshire and poured a clear copper color with a fat and very long lasting off-white head and very thick lacing. The nose is citrus and grassy  hops.  The body is medium and the mouthfeel somewhat slick and smooth.  The flavor is earthy malts and the finish is sort of an odd bitter, kind of like the beer was past its prime.
Pours orange-amber with a white head. The aroma is piney hops. The flavor is grassy hops with a strong malt backbone. Medium mouthfeel and carbonation.

Bottle. Poured clear copper color with a large frothy off-white head that was was lasting with excellent lacing. Moderate earthy hop and small malt aroma. Medium body with a dry slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where exceeded.

This was a true APA.  At first, I thought that it was supposed to be an IPA - I didnt read the label all that closely -  upon drinking, I thought that it was definitely PA, and not so strong.  Ruddy, cedar red, the label is a bit lame - I know what Smutty is going for on their retro, throwback, 60s nostalgia, but it isnt quite coming off.   Lots of herbal, vegetable notes.  Moderate hopping, mostly dry, a little woody.  Very drinkable.  Medium body, nutty/toasty/woody caste.
Wonderful Pale.  Great bitter taste of hops. So great. Wonderful color almost of an IPA.  I love this brew.
This is a good pale. Bitter ut not ove the top. Citrus flavors and a hoppy profile. Clean and refreshing with nice flavors.
Fresh baked bread anyone indeed. Decent brew. Must admit I prefer the Sierra version more and its cheaper, still very drinkable.

12oz bottle from ABC Liquor.  Copper pour with thin off-white head and a light sheet of sudsy stick.  Citrus hop aroma with a yeasty quality to it.  Grassy hop bitterness in the taste balanced by an earthy malt sweetness.  Slightly watery palate and low carbonation keep the focus on the bitterness through to the dry finish.
Hoppy and citrusy more like an IPA to me which is probably why I like it so much.  Although maybe all english pale ales are similar.  Very refreshing and tasty

(12 ounce bottle)  Smuttynose has a good looking bottle.  Pours a dense but small head,  has great head retention though which leads to a nice lacing.  Hoppy aroma with notes of pepper and citrus.  Crisp hoppy taste.  Carbonation is there though not at all overpowering,  light crisp finish.  5% ABV makes this a good session beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours a hazy copper color with a fine head of white foam that leaves a good amount of lace.  Grain and malty sweetness and a touch of floral hops make the aroma.    Great flavor balance goes from a citrus hop flavor to full sweet maltiness and finishes with a drying hop bitterness.  A decent Smutty.

a nice pale ale, however, the problem with pale ales in general for an IPA drinker is a lack of overall taste and flavor or body. this is a good example of that. nice refreshing PA taste and crisp palate, but it leaves you wanting more body.

This one poured a nice copper color with a white head. Aroma was slightly grassy, a bit sweet and some herbal and citrus musty hops too. Flavor was light crisp pale ale, nice balance if slightly bitter hops and pale malt.
12oz bottle. Your basic pale ale here. Very drinkable, nice caramel taste with just enough hops. Very well done though nothing out of the ordinary for this style.

Bottle.  Has the color of a tarnished penny and supports a dense but small head.  Aromas of caramel and peppery spices with a little bit of citrus.  Flavor has quite a bit of caramel and bready malt with lots of spice and bitter grassiness in the finish.  Pretty decent stuff.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle. Poured a clear pale golden, with a small white head.  Aroma of citrus hops, with lemon & orange coming through.  Some light sweet malt in there as well.  Taset is similarly straight forward, with the hops hitting early and in the finish, plenty of citrus and a sweet malt backing.  Mouth is medium.  Overall, a nice basic APA.

Aspetto brillante e interessante ambrata chiara dalla schiuma bianca e persistente.
Olfatto intrigante dalle morbide note di malto con sentori di caramello frutta secca e frutta caramellata con lievi sentori di tostato;la luppolatura è soffice e non eccessiva daalle leggere note verdi..
Al palato si presenta subito astringente e  mediamente amara ma subito ritornano la note restoolfattive percepite al naso più pronunciate  sulla nocciola senza nulla invidiare ad un nosiola del trentino..
In chiave generale ricorda molto una pale in stile inglese(vedi la perxcezione dei malti e dei luppoli) rivisitata in chiave americana(un amaro più pronunciato e astringente)...Good beer, very good!
Cheers..
Pane e birra!!
Poors golden amber and slightly cloudy.  Nice citrusy aroma.  Good malt and hop balance.  Bitterness very pleasant and hop flavor very nice.  A very good pale ale

A: Poured with an average-sized, off-white head... diminished after a couple of minutes to a thin film. Body is a dark golden color, and hazy.

S: Mmmm... APA goodness. Smells quite hoppy, with a little sweetness in there as well. I think I may detect some lemon/lime also.

T: Oh yeah, thats some good APA. Starts off lightly sweet and citrusy, and finishes slightly bitter. Not as bitter as I would have expected from the aroma... an excellent balance as it isnt overwhelming, yet provides a bit of everything, with a good duration.

M: Awesome on the palate as well. Medium-bodied and creamy, it rolls across the tongue perfectly. Average carbonation... just right.

D: A great APA; very easy to drink... this is a beer I could drink at the beginning or end of the night, and several of them. Quite floral, and very satisfying. My first Smuttynose beer, and Im looking forward to more in the near future (hopefully).

Serving: 12 oz. bottle.
Appearance: Hazy, deep amber with a frothy, light tan head.  Decent head retention. Spotty lacing left behind.
Aroma: Very fruity nose with hints of berry and caramel.  Kind of unique.
Taste: Caramel, solid balancing bitterness, berries, and a little earth.  A bit different than most pale ales, but well crafted and tasty.  Really good malt character.
Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium, crisp mouthfeel.  Medium-long, slightly bitter finish.
Overall: Highly sessionable, this one is definitely worth a go.  One of the better pale ales Ive had in recent days.

And now back to the beer at hand. She shimmers in a sea of crystal clear coppery depths with glints of amber and garnet where the light fractures her body. Her itsy bitsy puffy white head fades into a paper-thin film. As her head bows out, her nose steps onto center stage and demands attention. Crisp and hoppy followed by an array of sweet breads and grainy mats. Giving her a crisp presence are fresh lemons, apples, peaches, and oranges with a healthy sprinkling of cinnamon and nutmeg. Her cinnamon and spice come into play once more as she gathers all her crunchy toasted bread crusts, dip them lightly into honey, and sprinkles some of moms cinnamon sugar on top. Aromatically enticing and balanced, but will her main performance be able to hold up? She steps forward with brisk assurance which I find highly refreshing. Spices up front with the crunchy sweetness of her toasted and honey-dipped crust lead smoothly into bitter citric esters on the top of my tongue which hints of lemon skin. Unlike her initial pour, lace begins to leave their mark along the sides of my glass with each draining quaff. As she warms and we grow ever more intimate, a hint of maple is added to the fray, while her fresh baked breads add a pleasant meatiness which is balanced by her crisp hop presence. Not to be forgotten, crunchy apples, fresh pears, and succulent oranges weave in and out from start to finish. As her performance draws to a close, I call for an encore.
