Draught, sample @ Portsmouth brewpub. Rich amber color with interesting patterned lacing and capping. Bright roasted crystal malt nose and flavors. Clean quaffable thin, low carbonation, and leaves with a great hop bite in the finish. Very good session ale!

reddish amber pour with nice rising carbonation, very solid head, slow to die away. aroma is underwhelming, very straight-forward. Flavor has interesting bitterness and definitely hop presence, with a fairly watery mouthfeel, though a solid lingering aftertaste. Good contribution from smutty, nice beer.
UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 12 oz. bottle.  This really is one of my favorite beers, so criminally underrated, this is an outright phenomenal session beer.

6-2-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to joepais 
Murky brown amber in color with a slight ivory head.  Smell is doughy and yeasty.  Flavor is bitter and grassy and needs a touch more sweetness to balance.  Medium to high carbonation.  Overall, not bad and has present hops which I enjoy.

Bottle in trade from joepais (pastor). Thanks man!



Pours murky amber and is only very slightly transluscent.  Lasting beige head.  Smell is chalky, dusty malt and lightly hops in an earthy way.  Taste is moderately bittered with some earthy, dusty, bittering hops and a very light balancing maltiness that doesnt come through much at all in the flavor.  Nice crisp bitterness and full body with lively carbonation.  Pretty drinkable and has a good flavor.  A solid pale ale.

Another nice one from Smuttynose. Pleasent citrusy character, with a bright floral taste and grapefruit aroma. It pours a clear copper colour with a plentiful head, and a nice lacing. Hops are well integrated, not too overpowering, but well balanced and firm for an APA.

Pours a dark shade of orange, with some hints of amber in it-quite nice to look at actually. Off-white small finger head that turned into some nice lacing. 

Yeasty and hoppy notes dominate the aroma, some of an earthly smell too which I enjoy. 

Taste was spot on for what I was hoping for in a pale ale. A nice balance of maltiness and hops with some earthy tones. 

Goes down relatively smooth, good balance and not too strong on the ABV either. Carbonation is minor but pleasant. I could drink a couple more of these in a session. 

This is my favorite style of ale and it definitely lived up to what I was expecting.

Clear amber pour, with white crown that flees quickly. Not much nose, perhaps a bit of flour and yeast. Taste is pretty dry, and earthier than youd expect from a pale. Surprising hop presence, though not overbearing bitterness. Pretty good overall.

Quite watery and uneventful. The hops dominate the beer, leaving it quite one-sided in both aroma and flavor. The aroma has more malt character with some chocolate and maybe dark fruit. Body is orange with small white head.

Draft at the Portsmouth Brewery - Poured a reddish amber in color with a small white head.  Aroma was medium of hops and a slight amount of sweet malts.  Flavor was much the same.  Medium hop finish.  A good session beer... enjoyable...

On tap at Out of the Fire in Easton, MD.  I enjoyed this brew, my first time having the Shoals Pale Ale; I very much enjoy their IPA.  Pours rich golden color, medium head.  Aromas of citrus and pine; dry hop flavor.  Good overall brew and I will definitely have this again.
Had this on vacation at the Portsmouth Brewpub.  A nice dry pale ale, no florals, and earthy with a nice golden color.

From a 12 fl. oz bottle with an expiration date of August 2008. Pours a ruby-copper with an off-white head that stays atop the glass for the session.  A little hoppy on the nose.  The hops are in the flavor too but there are subtle malts too.  Not quite as bold as an IPA but it has some of those characteristics.

Beautiful dark copper body with a lightly off white head. The aroma is oranges and floral notes. There is a carmael hint. The taste has some bitter grapefruit rind with some burnt bread crust. There is also a little bit of musk and oak. There isnt much to balance out the bitter burnt type charcter.
Pours amber with tan head.  Aroma of fruit, bread and malt with a touch of pine.  Flavor is average, but blended nicely.

Aroma is slighlty bready with a grassy whiff of hops.  Color is copper with a medium head.  Flavor starts out with classic fruity ale esters, mellowing into a bready malt, brought to a firm close by an almost piny bitterness.  Palate is typical of American pale ale.  Overall, a lovely anytime beer that also harmonizes well with flavorful food.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2010 Rated 7/19/04.  Notes.  Deep amber-brown color which was darker than expected and pours with a nice thick tan head. Pretty smoooth, easy drinking beer, with a decent hop/malt balance but its lacking a little something. Theres a wood, piney presence in there as well. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Something Id definitely have again but not the best from Smuttynose.

Bottle. Aroma of somewhat roasted malt backed by mild hop. Coppery color with a decent off-white head. Medium body with very smooth carbonation. Sort of biscuit with spicy, fruity hop. Its not citrus or pine, I think. Ends well balanced on the dry side. Very interesting. Not overly hoppy, but hoppy enough. Sort of a rough ESB.

From the Smutty winter sampler...off-white single-finger head on an Octoberfest-type hue; lacing is of cirrus clouds...crunchy hops aroma-- not unlike their powerful IPA--welcoming and yeasty...medium-to-full body with slight effervescene; formidable mouthfeel...bright, punchy hops that splash the throat with an intense flourish early and vibrant tongue action; clean and crisp, malty and mellow late--complex...approaches the wonder and awe of Sierra Nevadas offering... I will seek this out in the barbecue season, as I can see this complimenting the grill fare well...
Not very hoppy for a Pale Ale. Was expecting a little more from Smuttynose since I enjoy a lot of their others

Nice label photo of an old house in a field.  Dark amber brew with a modest head.  Good aroma with yeast and floral tones.  This is a crisp, dry ale - a little on the light side, but still flavorful.  Light esters and astringency, a little yeast too.  A solid English-style ale.
Bottle:  Amber pour with a large, creamy off-white head.  Nose of sweet malt, toffee, caramel, and florals.  Malty taste with subtle fruity tones.  Toffee and bits of floral hops.  Thanks Imadeadguy.
A light IPA, that goes down real smooth.  Not a whole lot of after taste. Does tend to be a bit watery. I like the Shoals Pale Ale better - more taste

Smuttynose Shoals Pale Ale
ABV: 5%
IBU: ?
Calories: 150
Volume: 12 fl oz
Glass: tulip
Purchased at: Joe Canals in West Windsor
Consumed on/at: Thursday March 6th, 2008

sensory first impression: Lighter than even the Old Brown Dog ale by Smuttynose, and seemingly even more tame. Not my kind of beer, but I know some who would love it. Not very hoppy - smooth like water. Bright white head hangs on for a few. Tea colors and murky with nice sediment, if you like that sort of thing. I like it as a change of visual pace. Its another tea like brew from Smutty.

Aroma/Olfactory:
Malt flavor is: malty, nutty, and roasted. Malt has a bit of linger.
Hop flavor is: missing. Really very little in way of bitterness or hops here. After a moment, some bitterness arrives, but not enough to cheer.
Yeast flavor is: muddy, earthy, and dusty.
Other flavors include: grapefruit and other citrus hints.

Visuals/Appearance:
Color is: pale reddish brown, murky and tea like.
Liquid is: hazy, dark, and cloudy.
Head and lace are: bright white, and much more impressive than in SNs Old Brown Dog Ale. Lace is running strong, with nice legs.

Taste/Flavor:
Maltiness or Sweetness level is: medium
Hoppiness or Bitterness level is: light
Sour level is: none

Palate/Tactile:
Body or Mouthfeel is: too light
Texture is: thin and smooth.
Carbonation is: flat
Finish is: abrupt and unsatisfying.

Overall experience: Not bad, but nowhere near great. Rather disappointing, especially after having their IPA, which is surprising and delicious. About average or below for American styled craft beers.
not particularly pale, nor as hoppy as Id hoped. malty overall, with a slightly dry finish, more hop in the aroma than the flavour. cask at Brazen Head, Brooklyn
Draft. Pours dark. Not as hopped as indicated.  Just kind of nondememo  I am not happy to report.

12oz thanks beastiefan2k - Aroma is perfume hops followed by crystal and caramel malts.  Not a fan of perfume beers.  Pours cloudy brown with a medium head and good lacing.  Flavor is caramel and malty with an earthy hop finish.  Palate is sticky.  Ok, but may be a little past prime.
Bottle. Ice tea color with light hop aroma along with tea scent. Tea again evident in the flvaor. Mild hop presence. Easy drinking but nothing real special
Copying from my tasting notes. Bottle. Dark amber pour, with a dry hoppy aroma. Hop flavor through out, dry and tasty.

May 2006 - The great beer that wasnt.  Beer poured with nice little head and lacing, beautiful dark amber color.  Very little aroma.  The flavor, as it hit my tongue, I thought was going to be really, really good.  The sweetness and the maltiness never really developed. . .leaving me wanting more of both.  The hops were indistinguishable under the bitter finish.  Very little taste from the hops (again leaving me wanting more), just a bitter finish.  Its not a bad beer, but it disappointed me a little because I like the style and heard good things about this one.  Oh well.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 12 oz. bottle - Poured a really nice copper color with medium head and great lacing. Aroma is fruity and also has a light floral hop scent. Initial taste is slightly sweet and metallic on the tongue. leaves you with a dry finish. Overall a slightly above average EPA.

pours a hazy ruby copper with an off-white head.  aroma is tangy/tart hop, some floral notes, and a hint of apricot.  taste is some hops, some foral notes, some dough.  pretty much tastes like it smells.  taste is a bit on the watery side, but has a nice overall light bitterness to it.  mid-bodied with a crisp finish.  sudsy mouthfeel.  decent as a session-type refresher.  not the best APA ive ever had, its a bit too gentle/watery.

This beer could have gone either way. It wasnt bad, but neither was it good. I guess for me it really suffers the "plain jane" fate because while there were no flaws, it just didnt impress me enough to consider this beer anything more than "just another beer". The beer pours out a nice copper/amber color, solidly built head and an aroma of light flowers and some citrus zing. The problem I had was...wheres the flavors? I mean, with the aroma it was telling me that I might get a decent APA here, but it just didnt deliver no matter how much it warmed up. Sure there was some faint, soft caramel malts and some lifeless citrus hop bitterness but it was on life support. A ho-hum beer for sure. Next!

Cask at Deks American. I liked this ale very much as we had a pin of it sitting on the bar. Its hoppy aroma welcomed the first taste which found volumes of light to medium malts vying for attention. The previous notes about tang and yeast elements held true in my experience. I was not a fan of this in a bottle, but on cask its nature was revealed.

Pours dark amber with a hint of rust and a one finger head that dissapates into a film. Aroma was predominantly hops, of the grapefruit and lemon variety. Flavor was also largely dominated by hops, with a little malt sneaking in there. Hops had just a little too much bite on them, I feel like it would suit this beer better if they mellowed out and left space for other facets of flavorl. Aftertaste left an almost spicy feeling in my mouth, which subsided into a typical hop aftertaste.

Pours copper with two fingers-dissipating to one finger- of off-white head.  Nose is slightly spicy with notes of caramel malt, brewers yeast, floral hop, and a good amount of breadiness.  Flavor is tangy in the beginning with slight hop bitterness and pale malt backing.  Medium body.  Mediocre.
Bottle from sampler. Pours a hazy copper with a 1 inch thick creammy tan head. Flavor and aroma of malts, hops and spice. Very complex flavor for its style. Interesting

bottle from alldaydrinker...BB july/07. pours a hazy brown shade of copper with an off white head that slowly fades and leaves a U shaped ring of lacing in the glass. caramel sweet aroma with hints of peat, citrus, spice and cocoa. flavor is mainly malty plus earth, nuts?, orange and pine with a dry spicy hop finish. light lingering bitterness. medium body gets creamy as it sloshes around.

Pale Brown pour. Flavor is complex. Tangy fruit at the start possibley grapefruit with a  hop crispness and a somewhat malty finish. Description says highly hopped. I disagree. There is a good amount of hops in this brew but not enough to say its highly hopped. Otherwise this is a very good brew. Very good interpation of the style. Very drinkable. Will definitly have more of this.

Hazy bronze appearance with a medium size, off white head and good lacing.  Low keyed, spicy, piney aroma.  Bitter hop taste mellows as it finishes, producing an earthy, nicely balanced, medium-bodied, well carbonated  mouthfeel.  A good, all around, solidly made, easy to drink pale.

Pours a nice head with micro bubbles intermixed in with some larger bubbles; the head is somewhat persistent.  Has a nice dark amber color and a mild, but pleasant aroma, but thats where it stops for me b/c the taste and aftertaste just isnt that great in my opinion.
UPDATED: FEB 13, 2008 12 oz bottle. A nice ale, with a bit of hoppiness to it and a malty/citrus kick at the end.
From a bottle poured a nice amber color with a good amount of head.  Nice hoppy flavor with a quick lasting aftertaste.

12 oz bottle, courtesy of LooseCannon. Murky burnt orange with a small white head.  Pleasant orange nose, thick, sweet malt, some earthiness. The flavor does not quite live up to the promises made by the nose - somewhat bready with a herbal bite. Finishes quickly with a mildly dry bitter that fades rapidly. Pretty good.
12oz bottle. Pours cloudy amber in color with off white head. Aroma of malt and lite hops. Taste same as aroma with bitter finish.
12oz bottle, consumed about 20 min after Alpha King,  kind of weak tasting, not much going on here, but to its credit its quite "Pale" definite tang.....then the malt comes..meh.
Pours a clear orange amber with a thin head. Aroma of caramel and citrus. Good bitterness, but not enough malt to balance it out. Palate seems a little thin.
Moderate pine hop aroma. Clear orange color with a medium white head. Gets bitter toward the end and fades a little in the finish.

Cask at GGBF.  Pours out in a clear aple amber colour with a low white foam. Caramel, grass, grapefruit and breadchrusts in the aroma. Medium-bodied with notes of caramel, bread, grass and citric fruit. Medium bitter finish of citric fruit.

Cask @ GBBF 2007. Pours a clear copper color with a small off-white head. FRuity malty and hoppy aroma with hints of caramel and citrus. Malty caramel flavor with hoppy citrus hints. Dry finish and very bitter aftertaste.

This pale ale pours a light copper color with a thick, off-white head.   It has a pleasant aroma comprised of a complex mixture of malt and hops.   Nice flavor and malty palate.  Has a slightly bitter, grassy/floral hops finish.  Another fine beer from Smuttynose!

This is a solid offering for a pale ale, which as a style, has its limitiations in a high octane IPA world...but, its refreshing with spicy food and a little smoky on the palate...it tastes like a weak pussy fart compared to its big brother The Smuttynose Robust Porter...so what the fuck
Good smooth beer with beautiful poured  off white head. Delicious with nice steak.
Clear amber with little head.  Hoppy, but not overly hoppy, well balanced with malt and herbal notes.  More in the English style.   Dry slightly bitter finish.  Medium to thin body.
Bottle sampled. Pours a light amber with a white head. Aroma of light hops, citrus, and pale malts. Flavoris medium bodied with caramel, and light fruitness with a floral bitter finish.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.

Pours from the bottle to a nice copper color, with thousands of infused carbonation bubbles and a thick off-white head that lingers thru most of the glass and leaves very good lacing. Aroma is predominantly citrus hops (grapefruit and lemon) but also a hint of malt. Flavor follows suit perfectly, begining with the hoppy citrus fruit, then slowly moving to a hint of malty dark fruit.

Finish is not very bitter, but is a nice mixture of being dry from the hops and sweet from the malt.

I had read a lot about Smutty and was excited to try one. My first was a Portsmouth Lager, which I found disappointing. However, this Shoals Pale Ale exhibits all the quality I had expected. Good job Smutty!

Pours a cloudy amber brown with no head. Nose is citrus hops and a good bit of them. Flavor is slightly salty with a hop edge. Even flavor pattern. Feel is standard. Nice level of bubble on the tongue and a smooth thicker liquid feel. Very drinkable. A smooth and solid pale ale.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2011 Slight swirl in the pour of this 12 oz bottle. Some gunk on the bottom afterwards. Yeasty aroma with a slight metallic hint. Very bitter medicine that hangs for quite a while. Intense citrus rind bang that fades rapidly only to leave a building bitter lingering soap finish.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Smells very well balanced between malty sweetness and citrusy hops. Pours a nice deep orangish copper color. Taste is balanced hops and malts. A little more hops wouldnt hurt though.

Quite a brownish heavy color for a "pale" ale - surprisingly close in color to the brown ale.  Hops evident right in the smell, quite heavy for the style.  But nicely balance with a reasonably rich malty without being too heavy.  Dry finish. Very nice overall effect but more of a bitter than a "pale ale".

9th of my 10 tasting flight @ Portsmouth.  Pours light amber with a bright white ring head.  Nose is light but there are little notes of hops.  Taste is lightly spicy with a nice hop kick.  Very nice Pale.

Cask gravity @ GBBF 2007, London. Clear medium amber color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, pine, grapefruit. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long duration and a nice dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2009 355 ml, bbe Nov 07. Slight haze in this new penny colored beer with a medium head that really lasts well, leaving some sticky lace. Nose is spicy dried fruit (almost berry-like), toasted nut and caramel. Flavor pits some dry-bitterish, fruity and earthy-spiced hops and yeast against an underlying malt sweetness that has some chocolate, nut, coffee, and brown sugar tones. Medium-bodied and smoothish; drying and tingly on the tongue. Excellent EPA.

touch of bitters, tasty

Light amber, off-white head, fair lace. Sweet, fruity, grassy, sticky mouthfeel. Nice but nothing to get excited about.

A Mes rate: 
Gravicask at GBBF. Tea brown colour. Slickly hoppy nose. Way too o.t.t. and grassy flavour. If I wanted to munch grass Id turn into a cow and move into a field.
Poured from bottle, very drinkable but nothing special. Not very hoppy. Had a bit of tang to it.

Pours straight copper, with a little bit more carbonation than I would typically expect in a high quality beer, but that was ok. Beige colored head that looked pretty nice. Flowery and slightly hoppy aroma. SOme citrusy fruitiness in the taste, but overall we got a smooth beer with some nice hops and malts abounding.

Bottle.  Went into this one expecting an American style Pale Ale - nonetheless a nice English Style Pale Ale. Dullish copper color with a lasting, huge, cream colored head.  Woody, resinous and crisp with a malty backbone that makes this beer very legitimate.  Nice clean, not overly hoppy finish evens this EPA out very well.  A very nice Ale.  My full rec.

Had this straight from a keg purchased at State Line Liquors in MD.  Poured a deep copper brown with a frothy, creamy, slightly tan head.  Aroma was malty and fruity, but not too citrus.  Flavors were perfectly balanced; sugary and malty but also a tad citrusy and tangy.  Finish is clean, with a touch of lasting bitterness.  Very drinkable, great session beer.
350 mL bottle.  Orange amber with a fizzy white head.  Grapefruit and caramel aroma.  Crisp citrus and pine taste with a bitter finish.

Aroma very hoppy: dry, astringent; some malt in the aroma too.  Flavor is very unusual for any beer: subdued, the bitterness is strong but highly muted, and late to arrive.  Something in the aroma emerges which is highly suggestive of roast, although I think it is actually an unusual hop bitterness.  There is some stuff about it that I do not like, however.  There are too many flavors at once...the suggestion of roast seems inappropriate.  Also I think the brew is too heavy.  Also, theres an aftertaste that is metallic and tastes of caraway, that Im not too fond of.
Bottle Copper pour with no head. Light hop aroma, good citrus hop flavor. A bit earthy too. Good session brew.

En fût. Verre de dégustation dégusté chez Portsmouth Brewing Co. (Porstmouth, NH). Arôme: Odeur dagrumes fruités. Apparence: La couleur est cuivrée avce une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dagrumes et de pin. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence damertume en arrière goût. (Rating #1121)

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2011 From 12 oz. bottle with drink by date of 11/07. 
Decent head with same lacing. Amber/reddish color. Light-to-medium body with some fizziness. A relatively easy drinking beer with some decent hops to it. Im not a hop fiend myself, so I think it was about right. 

Re-rate: wow, this is better than I remember. Nice bready backbone, nice citrus hops (Chinook and Cascades, according to the website). Slightly bitter finish.

Poured from bottle.  Looks like most other pale ales, cloudy dark amber, rugged head.  Hops in aroma, not overpowering tho.  Flavor quite nice, hops are delicious, not too grapefruity.   Creamy malt feel supports flavor well.  Long lasting head with lacing.  A fine pale ale.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Smoke and country ham aroma. Dark copper color with a tan head. Earthy and mossy taste. Grapefruit finish. Not terribly great tasting, but unique in its complexity.

Pours golden with a nice white creamy head. Looks good! Faint, faint aroma. Mainly yeast, malt and bread. Tastes rich, with some hops and a bit of bitterness. Smooth, but a real skunk aftertaste; reminiscent of Heineken or equal. Makes me think of an upscale macro. Real good on the first sip, then subsequent sips either A) didnt taste good or B) tasted bad or C) all of the above. Other Smuttynose selections were tastier.

Pours a cloudy light amber color with a thin, small head.  The lacing produced thin ringlets down the pint glass.  The scent wasnt dominating, but did produce some notes of citurs and hops.  The mouthfeel was a little on the thin side as the hops and malt balanced eachother nicely.  An average beer, not bad to have a sixer around in an emergency.

Bottle.  Poured a cloudy orange-brown color with a thick off-white head.  Lots and lots of lacing.  Very pleasant aroma with a nice citrus kick.  Flavor was bitter and hoppy, but not nearly as good as I thought this would be with its nice aroma.  Grapefruit juice aftertaste.  Very bitter, but not as flavorful as I would have hoped.  Still a very above average pale ale.

12oz bottle, again nothing too special here, smuttynose makes nice session beers but nothing to go wild about. poured a golden amber color with quickly disappearing head, light body with citrus taste, hop taste on the finish, decent pale ale.

Bottle.  Pours a darker, sort of cloudy amber with a limited head.  Nose was lightly citrus with some funky/off-smelling notes.  Flavor initially was a continuation of that off smelling nose.  After the beer warmed,  this settled out and dissapated.  However, the beer was never anything special, OK at best.  Thanks to Wild4mild for the bottle.

Not a bad choice.... Pours deep hazy amber into the glass with a perfect head... pock-marked and stiff, almost like eggwhites.  Citrus, hops and candy fruit rings are on the nose.  Very crisp and biscuity, pale malts quite evident (Crystal, it seems primary) with a high-hop cleanliness to the palate.  Long finish, bready.  Overall, good integration between bitters and biscuit malt.

Light citrus hop aroma, a little apricot, surprisingly bitter first impression, orange peel hop bitterness, some malt balance, wow its odd how that bittering hop dominates If bittering is ok with you as it is with me, this is a serviceable brew,but an English Pale Ale,no way

Brown sugary aroma. Soft mouthfeel. Actually, on the dry side not so sweet. An unpronounced flavor profile with a touch of tabacco. All the flavor is in the back end finishing with lots of hops resin.

Bottle: This is an underrated English Ale. Pours a nice cloudy bronze/amber color with a substantial tan head. Has a great fruity hop aroma; some golding/fuggle, and blood orange suggestions. Also has an earthy malt component with a hint of oats. Flavor is no disappointment. Upfront it has peppery fruity flavors. Earthy hop characteristics with some dark citrus notes. Has a toasty bready malt background and a hint of caramel sweetness. The finish is rich, bready and bitter. This is a very solid English Pale Ale.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2011 Red apple skin.  Peppery, spicy hops.  Mossy.  Toffee.  Big malty base.  Pretty thick mouthfeel.  Some nice flavors, but lacking complexity and depth.  Good beer, but Smutty can do even better.
Pint- Poured GoldishAmber coloring, light to medium bodied, with a citrius/hoppish aroma.  I was overall not impressed.  It seemed slightly off so I plan on trying it again.

Pours a cloudy amber colour with a fizzy off white medium head.  Aroma is citrus hops and mild malts. Taste begins with a citrus hoppy slap finishing with a malts on the palate. I feel the body was lighter than expected. Medium Carbonation. Slight finishing lacing of the glass.
A nice session drinker.  Light hop aroma and light hop flavor.  Some malt, and a medium palate.  Orange in color.  It is very drinkable, and quite mild.
Reddish gold color with thin lacing on the edges.  Malt and faint floral hops on the nose.  Bitter hop finish.

Thanks goes to Brewfiend for sharing this one. From a 12-oz bottle (picked up at the Coffee Grounds in Eau Claire, WI), pours a dark coppery amber with a medium off white head. Dissolves fast and leaves behind no film or lacing. Aroma of citrus hops, honey, and biscuits. Flavor is earthy at first and then finishes smooth and creamy.
Amber body, medium off-white head with some lacing, English hops in the nose. Bready, slightly sweet, herbal hoppiness, not bad.

bottle- copper in color, off white head, fairly lacing, smells of malt and english hops, ken goldings perhaps. alcohol detected in taste, some grassyness, but mostly malt with some bitterness in the finish. A nice option for those not in the west coast ales dominating the market, but since I am into those, I wont pick this up again.

A top of the line EPA. Aroma of earthy hops but not too strong. Pour was a beautiful hazy orange with no head. Taste was all toffee and malt in the beginning followed by a bitter earthy hop aftertaste. Nice and crisp and perfectly carbonated.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This pours a hazy amber body with a short-lived beige head.  The aroma is toffee, wildflowers, and damp soil.  Medium bodied, it tastes of caramel and a light fruitiness with a mild floral bitter finish.  Sessionable.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine and Spirits, Whitefish Bay, WI<font size=-1>

bottle . . pours cloudy deep amber . . white head . . aroma is citrus, clover, hops, dried fruit . . taste is hops, peach, bitter, floral . . its a unique beer . . pale ale? . . possibly . . but im very impressed with this smuttynose sampler pack . . good beers

12 oz bottle from variety pack.  Copper color, white head that dissipates quickly, average flavor, mouthfeel and palate.  I would agree about the sourness.  A touch of bitter hoppiness, getting it close to IPA territory, but not quite.  Similar to the porter in that there is a bit of over-bitterness, which I wouldnt expect out of a PA.  Not one of the best pale ales Ive had.

Earthy aroma.  Light tan, medium head.  A little sour, bitter, light body.  Not very crisp at all really - drinkable but theres a sourness that lingers in the aftertaste.  I think theres some major local bias going on here, drinkable not such a great PA.
This beer was poured into and pint class with a decent head and had the smell of malt and hops. the taste was apricot and had a bitter bite afterwards.

Pours a light amber color with a cream head.  Smells lightly of floral hops. Nice lacing in the glass. Taste is mildly bitter hops, fresh apricot, pineapple and fresh cut grass. Dry ending. Good beer here.

12 oz. bottle via trade with jasonmech77 - Pours a clear amber color with a one and a half finger thick off white head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is light pine, grass, and light toasted malt.  Flavor is bitter hops.  Light to medium body.  Slightly dry palate.  A good beer.  Thanks Jason.
Amber pour with thin off white head.  Aroma of hops and malt.  Taste of hops and some maple nutty flavor.  Great hoppy finish, thick for a pale.
Pale Amber Color with White Head.  Subtle Musty Malt Aroma.  Well Carbonated Malty Body.  Subtle Sweet and Dry Malt. Balanced With Low-Keyed Hops... Dry, Sweet and Refreshing.
Firm hops, almost pushing it into IPA territory.  Nice malt sweetness with a tiny hint of maple syrup.
Id agre that this is a nicely balanced beer. Almost as hoppy as a ipa though. Has an almost musty aroma that is lovely. somewhat refreshing although your not gonna want to chug this one.
Orange/amber with a white head.  Aroma of pine and sweet malt.  Flavor is full and malty, with a spicy hop finish. Solid and enjoyable.
Light amber color. Smooth, hoppy bitter aftertaste but not in a bad way.  Refreshing and well balanced. An ok beer.
Bottle.  Caramel brown color.  No head.  Hoppy with hints of spices.  Tastes very similarly, esp with pepper note.

Poure a darker golden color with good head and great lacing.  Aroma was very sharp hops.   Flavor was unbalanced at best, tasted like i was chewing on an orange rind with some pine on it.  Needed some malts to balance out the hops.
UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 For an english pale ale, this has the hops of an american pale. It has a nice different taste to it that suggests its not simply an american pale. A great beer!

Bottle. Orange-amber color with a slight haze. Medium head with fair lacing. Aroma is big time caramel malts and a little earthy hops. Taste brings out some spicy flavor hops. Light to medium body. Slightly bitter finish. Not setting the world ablaze, but its still pretty good.

Bottle: Amber in color with an off white head. Aroma, more malty than anything with some spicy hops. Flavor, caramel, molasses, up front with a dry spicy hoppiness to back it up. Nice bit of bitterness to it.

The off-white head vanishes quickly to reveal a slightly hazy red-amber body.  This doesnt look "pale"!  The aroma is of light malt and moderate pine and citrus from the hops.  It is a straightforward and well-balanced whiff.  The flavor is simple-- well bittered from start to finish.  It has a thicker body than I expected and a somewhat oily texture.  This is more like an ESB that a Pale, but its quite good.

Pours an ok color. But this is just an ale. THe smell is above average in my opinion for an ale. The taste has a nice bite to for an ale. The mouth feel is really good foe an ale. The drinkability is good for an ale. I could really sit back and just crack these open and down them.

This is what beer should look like ... medium orange with a incredibly mesmerizing swirl of carbonation that doesnt quit for anything rising into a thin 1/4-inch but cozy blanket of off-white puckered foam.  The aroma has an almost merengue character... but with a distinct citrus quality.  Creamy from the first quaff, this smooths into a nice silky brew as you go.  Tangy, fruity, chewy like an orange rind, but in a mellow, restrained way.  Big malty body.  Good ale!  (#2665, 1/27/07)

Pours copper/amber with a small off-white head. Semi-sweet doughy malt aroma, with a nice note of hop presence. Big roasted malt, doughy flavor, with a big hop bite in the finish. Medium, bitter-sweet palate. Almost a cross between an English and an American pale ale. Big malts, and big hops

12 oz bottle. Good looking beer with a clear amber color and an off white head. Aroma is of light hops and perhaps some cereal. Full mouthy feel with a nice hops malt balance in the flaovr. This is a great Pale Ale and a great beer all around.

Bottle.  Copper colored with a mostly lasting off-white head.  Bands of lacing. Dark bread malt and lightly sweetened cereal aromas. Caramel and cereal malt flavors with some citrus/apple esters and a nicely bitter hop twinge on the finish.  Medium bodied and pretty well balanced.  Ideal session brew.

Bonus bottle from ty5592! Thanks Ty! Pours a hazy amber with an off-white head. Nose is a mixture b/t light hops and light malts. Flavor is equally appealing.An easy drinking, and very tasty pale ale. A full body despite its low alcohol content. I used to live in new england and have had this many times, but I am just beginning to understand how powerful this beer is. A well done pale ale.
Bottle (rating from August 2005 notes).  Amber color with a tan head.  Malty with a good hop balance.  Somewhat bitter and dry with a full roasted flavor.

Bottle from Santa.  Clear, deep amber colored with a nice red presence.  Nice off white head and nice lacing.  Aroma is caramelish and it almost seems like someone snuck in some special-B in there somewhere.  Medium bodied.  Fairly malty with a more than ample lasting hop bitterness.  Not bad, a little different but pretty drinkable.

An amber pour with an off white head and a guey lacing that clings like a leach. A light hops aroma with malt bringing up the rear. A surprising hops bite on the taste that just wasnt there in the nose. A maltiness in the flavor that gets its ass kicked by the hops. A good bitter finish.  The palate is just a tad on the watery side but the carbonation is good. Another pale ale that I enjoyed and would love to drink again.
12. oz. bottle. Pours a dark gold color with a white head. It has a grassy aroma as well as grassy and dry taste.

Copper red slightly murky body with only a film of offwhite head.  Smells hoppy bitter and citrus, as well as some malt.  Very planty/piney.  Hop flavor is really complex.  Malt is there, but this is a hop foward beer. Having said that, this bottle expired October of 06, so Im sure its mellowed out.  Medium bodied, but little carbonation to speak of.  A nice little beer.

This pale ale comes off as more of an IPA than an American Pale Ale. Aroma is of light flowery hops, and alcohol. Pours a medium amber color with a sparkling body, covered by an average frothy head. Initial flavor is signficantly bitter, mellowing by the finish to a light bitter. Oily texture on the finish with lively bubbles.
A decent brew but has a bit of a watered down taste, but not nearly as dilluted as traditional American beer.
[bottle] Sweet, hoppy aroma. Clear orange color, with a minimal head. Nice earthy malt flavors, with some slight fruit and bright, grassy hops towards the end.
Just a really solid drinking beer.  Great color and taste.  I enjoyed this one a lot.
I love this brewery. A Pale Ale  that was deep copper with a great hop nose with even a bit of toffee tossed in. A very tasty brew that was better that a shit load of IPAs. Very nice brew indeed.

Not a very strong aroma, some yeast notes in there.  A cloudy dark amber with a small head.  This beer has a very thin, but strong nose that is biting.  Then it turns into a subtle malt flavor.  Its weird, but I guess it works.  This is a very contemplative beer, not something that Id like to enjoy by the fireside, or drink by the case, but something to save for a rainy day.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 This beer came to me in my beer club. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a ruby-caramel color with a medium sized yellow-tan head. The aroma is nutty malts and floral hops. The flavor is vague bitter fruity hops with a bit of nutty malts and a tangy finish. The beer is lacking in sufficient malt body and comes off as being a little thin.
A yeasty hoppy aroma from a heady pour into a mass of orange amber.  Very nice medium bodied pale ale with pleasant bitterness that invites you to have another.

Coppery clear body. Creamy off-white head.
Aroma is caramelly sugary malt with some hops thrown on top. Kind of basic.
Flavor is a bit of the same but with some added light alfalfa. 
Okay beer, but no uniquness.
From bottle.  Deep amber pour with tan head.  Nose has lots of grain, grassy hops and caramel.  Flavor follows with a light bitter finish.

An above average, quality pale.  Falls in with a large group of tasty ales that really dont distinguish themselves from each other.  A nice balance of hops and flavor.   I had one of these after a Bass Pale and this one is a much truer tasting pale.  There were no negatives with the Shoals.
Hazy orange on color with small white head. Citrus smell and taste. Nice body with good sharp bitter finish.

Pours reddish copper with frothy off-white head.  Nicely carbonated and inviting.  The nose is sweet and hoppy.  The beer taste mostly bitter to me from start to a lingering finish.  Crisp on the palate.

12 oz bottle.  Clear brown with a frothy oatmeal head.  Gets craggy.  Woody with a touch of brown sugar.  Bitter orange and grapefruit pith.  Juicy finish.  Grows on you.  Light carb.  Body gives just enough to chew on.
Chalky mineral taste with little hops. I love pale ale Smuttynose IPA so had high hopes for this. Unfortunately Shoals was barren, thin, and dreary just like the landscape on the label.

bottle - This beer has a light amber pour with a moderate head.  Quality hops make for a pleasant aroma.  It tastes moderately hoppy with well balanced caramel malts.  The finish is bitter and seems a touch off.  This is pretty good.
Bottle. Pale amber look with decent head. Good taste that has a slight spice to it. Very smooth but not a great ale. Decent.
Cold 12oz bottle:  Light alabaster head with a dark amber color.  Aroma is of hops and fruit.  Taste is crisp, malty & bitter.    Nice ending.

Solid copper coloration and a pillowy white head.  Nice aromas are bready and grapefruit.  Flavor is a definite bonus on this beer.  Lots of malts, a nearly choclaty finish, and a genuine integration of citrus fruit at the front end.  Tart and mellow at once.  Palate is a wee bit harsh and grainy, a forgivable shortcoming.

Bottle. Pours copper with a medium head. Aromas of caramel and a hint of hoppy bitterness. Flavor is on the bitter side. Initially it is on the malty side with caramel notes but then it gives way to fairly harsh bitterness. I would say that the beer is a bit unbalanced.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear amber body with a moderate off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, floral, hint of fruit, and cocoa.  Clean caramel and mild hops flavor.  Descent English Pale Ale.

12 oz bottle, poured into a pint glass. Amber color, small head, strong nose of toasted grain. Biscuit and apricot taste upfront, again, toasted, and a strong dry hoppiness at the back. Medium to high carbonation. Im not a huge fan of pale ales, but this one was a good example of the style.

bottle-thanks to the_eppest for this one.  clear caramel amber with a small off-white fizzy head.  big malty nose for a pale-toasted grains, lightly earthy hops (shoveled earth).  pretty complex for a low abv beer.  earthy, dark fruits and amber malts dominate the flavors with lots of toasted malt flavor.  fairly dry earthy hop finish that was very pleasant, drying things out.  body is medium with a good carbonation level (slick and somewhat sticky).  very nice pale.

12 oz. bottle from BOTMC.  Drank on 7/26/06.  Bottle conditioned.  Slightly cloudy, copper, 1" off-white / light tan head.  Rocky.  Thick layer of foam sticks around.  Nice lacing.  Aroma - Some sweet maltiness, some of that chinookish hop aroma - need to figure out how to describe that.  Avg. strength.  Some citrus / orange mostly.  Flavor - Nice mellow pale ale.  Decent up front bitterness, well balanced in the middle.  Nice malt and hop flavors in the finish - little sweetness, some of that chinook / centennial flavor.  Some cascade / orange flavor.  Palate - nice medium body, avg. carb.  Overall - good APA, not great, but good.  Easily drinkable and tasty.

Light, fluffy head leaving behind a coating of bubbles on the surface.  Nice bright amber color.  Predominantly hoppy flavor, but nicely balanced by maltiness and the flavor of roasted grains.  Pretty solid.

From the Beer of the Month Club. 12 oz. Bottle. Pour is dark copper with a thick fluffy light tan head and sticky lacing. Fruit, caramel malt, and bread. Same for the flavor with a good hop bitterness in the finish. Refreshing. Well made brew!

Pours amber with quarter inch beige head.  Aroma is strong with hops.  Taste is malt in the front with medium sour, bold hops all the way through the end.  Smooth drink and hops are not overpowering.  Good pale ale.

In the bottle from the July 2006 Beer-o-the Month Club. Thanks to pman. This is just a beautiful beer. Amber with a pillowy beige head of extreme retention. Has a pine and citrus aroma of hops. Medium body and bitterness. Has a strong tart flavor at first, but a fine and delicate berry flavor then emerges. Finishes with a quick bitterness. This has the thickest head that Ive ever seen on a pale ale. It leaves a floating discoid of foam that is nearly solid in texture.
UPDATED: SEP 14, 2006 Small white head, amber color. Grapefruit citrus aroma and flavor. Very hoppy but the aftertaste is a bit metallic & bitter. Nice ale, above average but just barely.

this was a very good english pale ale.  Dark copper body with a nice fluffy off white/tan head that sticks to the glass.  full flavor and aa nice hop bite - finishes very dry and making you want another one.  Smuttynose is a  brewery sneaking up on Dogfish head

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2014 12oz bottle in Waltham, MA.Golden colour with short-lasting white head. Buttery malty taste, slightly acidic on the palate. (27Jul2006-7/3/6/3/14=3.3)
On tap at the Book & Bar, Portsmouth, NH, at 5.6% ABV. Hazy amber with a ring of white head; a hoppy aroma; and a light, spritzy hop taste; the finish is dry and long lasting. (1Mar2014-6/3/6/3/12=3.0)
Poured nice foamy head, lots of hops, tempered bitterness, with delicate sweetness-malt, citrus, lemon grass.  tPleasant after taste.  medium carbonation.   Above average

Pour of ambered golden. Aroma of buttery sweet hop candies and aged tannins. Rich strong golden malt beams through with plums and lemon sugars. Tangy butter fire of grapefruit and pine resins. The finish is reticent with hop sugars, almonds and grapefruit skin resins. I dont feel that it really follows the style, but its damn decent.

Pour a translucent copper amber with an average fluffy off white head that left lacing.    Aroma of your standard english pale ale malts, some fruits and citrus and light hops.  Flavor was toasty malts, light hop bitterness with some light pine.

amber/copper, with a medium to thick long lasting sticky off white head.  Aroma is sweet malts, some light fruit and hops, taste is malty, bitter up front, sweet in the middle with a light dry and hoppy bitter finish.  very good.

Ah, not my cup of tea. Cracked this one open thinking it was another decent American Pale Ale. The pour was pretty colored for a pale ale, rich copper, a very nice initial head that had excellent retention. The lacing was also very solid, looked very much like an altbier, a very pretty beer. The aroma was all bitter, not a lot going on. The first two sips were a little pine-like with some citrus rind type flavors. However, the after taste was strong bitter hops without much flavor, sending a zingy-ness across the tongue.  After about three sips, I was convinced this was more English hopped than American and realized it was indeed an English PA. However, unlike the usual English PA, this thing seemed as hopped as much as the usual American PA in terms of hop strength. Malt underneath was hardly detectable, slight caramel and thats about it. Highly imbalanced, not enough hop flavors or other flavor complexity. Mouthfeel was moderate to light-moderate with average carbonation. Somewhat dry finish.

Appearance: lightly hazed, amber/copper color, creamy, stable head. Lookin good...

Aroma: malty, sharply fruity, sweet, hops get louder over time, but play it cool at the front. Nice enough.

Taste: Full bodied, bold entry on the palate, flush with fruity flavor. Bright, brash taste, quickly drying on the tongue. This feels like a meatier ESB, and doesnt taste like any pale ale, American, British, or otherwise...more of an amber ale, actually, especially with the lopsided malt-to-hop quotient. 

Drinks down smooth, with plenty of flavor all the way through. Another meeting with a Smuttynose ends far from disappointment.

orange body with a tan head. huge head. this beer is way too carbonated. conservative pouring produced such a head i had to let it settle for a good five to ten minutes to pour the rest. aroma nice caramel malt balancing out floral (roses) slightly soapy hops. flavor sweet toasty malt and bitter floral hops. nicely balanced. medium body. finish long and bitter. carbonation out of control. way way too fizzy. very solid pale ale that i enjoyed quite a bit except for the out of control carbonation. i need to try this one again. i think i might have had a bad bottle.

Here we go. Poured in a Smithwicks glass. Dark brown color, off white head. Aroma is dark fruit and sweetness. Fruit cake ish  Flavor is mostly boring, not enough hops, sweet, doesnt remind me of a pale ale at all....

Bottle.  Clear dark amber body under a thin wreath of white foam.  Roasty, caramelized raisin with a touch of melon in the aroma.  Kind of dull.  The flavor brings out some brighter lime citrus and dandelion stem hops but otherwise sticks to the same toasty malt base.  Decent stuff.
Pours a light amber color.  Aromas of fruit, hops, and light caramel malt sweetness.  Flavor is hoppy but a well balanced mixture of hops and malts, with a nice citrus taste.

Pours to a very transparent glowing copper orange body with lots of tiny bubbles rising up through the body.  The beer has a rocky white head.  The aroma is strange oranges, English floral hops, and cookie dough.  The flavor is cookie dough, floral hops, minerally.  The palate is lightly bitter, something doesnt sit right.  Not a fan.

Pours a nice dark amber color wioth a medium head.HAs a big malty aroma with some hints of citrus hops.Nice malty caramel flavor followed by a very nice hop bitter.More hoppy than most pales.Very good!

12oz. Bottles:  Smells malty and like cookie dough, hay,and hazelnut.  Poured copper in color.  Sparkling and full of particles.  Nice, medium-sized, frothy, off-white head.  Medium lacing.  Flavor is off.  Its a bit earthy.  Very malty.  No "tangy fruit" or "hop crispness."  A little watery.  Lively carbonation.  Light body.  Medium & thin.    Long finish.  Not very good, but drinkable.  Perhaps a bad bottle?

Bottle. Pours amber with a nice frothy off white head, spotty lacing. Faint citrus hop aroma. Initial taste of toasty and caramel malt offset by spicy hop bite. Bitter finish is dry with a leafy hop flavor, and some nuttiness. English??? Possibly in the malt profile, but the aggression of the hops seems more american. Not bad, but not as good as many of their other beers.

pours slight amber, mild off white head.
aroma smells of roses, caramel, and hops.
 nicely balanced hop and malt profile.
flavor lingers slightly in typical pale ale fashion. nice.

Bottled.  Poured a clear medium caramel with a short cap of off-white head... nice lacing followed it down.  English bittering hops are dominant in the nose... with notes of citrus, earth, and a solid dose of caramel backing.  Flavor picked up a crusty French-bread and caramel malt backing with bunch of grapefruit and leafy hops all round the palate.  Lighter-bodied with a sweet and bitter finish.  Enjoyed it.

A very light floralish summer smell.  Is a deep orange/amber and is fairly hazy with an average amount of carbination.  It has almost no head, except for about a fourth an inch of white foam on top.  Has a bitter taste, with an almost fruity sour aftertaste.   Feels thick and like a beer that is good to end a summer day with, but could not drink too many at once

12oz bottle.  Low carbonation, sour (British bitter style?) hops.  This is one of the best domestic british style beers that I have had.  I love this brewery... Ive always been a fan of their mix 12 pack and the big beer series... they are all tasty beers from down the road in New Hampshire.

Bottle in the bar of the Back Bay Hilton Boston where we stopped Dec 05 there is a fantastic range of bottled beers in this hotel bar. A most attractive label I must say. The beer poured a deep golden ok maybe copper colour with a small head. Plenty of hops in the aroma, hops and grapefruit in the flavour dept and a nice refreshing crisp bite to this beer.

Bottle: Poured a dark brown color ale with a small bubbly off-white head with average retention. Aroma is quite hoppy with a nice floral touch. Taste is also hoppier then expected with a great presence of citrus hops. Body is about average for the style with some low carbonation.

Bottle.  Copper colored, medium white head, with nice lacing.  Very hoppy, soap aroma, and slightly malty.  FLavor is extremely hoppy, with a diverse flavor of hops--citrus, pine, soap, and a grassy aftertaste.  Would like a little more body, but this is a good beer.

Bottle. Copper clear pour witjh small head.  Citrus grassy hop aroma with some amount of caramel malt.  Light toasty caramel malt flavors, balanced decently with citrus hops.  Moderate bitter finish.  Smooth beer.  Well done.

12 oz bottle.  Deep golden beer, thick off-white/yellow head.  Sweet citrusy hop aroma, very cascadey.  Flavour is well-balanced, grapefruit and a bit of pine but it is backed by a solid toasty sweet malt flavour.  A hint of caramel and toffee.  Even some very faint chocolate going on.  Low to moderate bitterness but decent hop flavour.

(bottle - 12 oz) Cloudy copper color with a very thin and lasting white head. Bitter aroma with a hint of malt underneath it all. Mostly bitter hops though. Taste begins with a light malty flavor that gives way to a nice and crisp hop bitterness and a nice and smooth bitter finish. The aftertaste is slightly malty with a touch of hops. A little watery, but thats the only negative thing about this one. Very good.

Medium concentration of malts and milder levels of hops. Mild fruit mash notes. Orange/amber color with a pinky thin than head. Smoothe balanced, fruity, malts with a nice hop balance. Its well put together, but to me lacks any oomph and suffers for it.
Bu au Mondial de la Bière 04. Un goût assé légé, pas trop complexé, un peu fruité. Pas mauvais.

(Bottle, brewed in 10/05) Pours amber with a soft biscuit head. Aroma has faint notes of vanilla and pine, with faint malt and hops. Pretty good lacing. Mouthfeel dryish, watery. Taste: mostly just medium bitter with nothing behind it. Bitterish aftertaste. Disappointingly bland flavor. Nice looking but bland.
Nicely hopped, just a really nice tasty pale ale.  Smuttynose has a nose for creating good beer.  This one is no exception.  If the label says one thing, believe it.
Bottle.  Alright pale ale.  Slight caramel, hoppy flavor.  Amber color, small white head.

Bottle:  Aroma of light chocolate and caramel with some flowery hops.  Pours a hazy amber with a small off-white head.  Light caramel up front with a moderate flowery hopped and slight roasted nut finish.
Hoppy, malty, strong bodied: this well-rounded beer is complex if you want it to be, or an easy refreshing drink if thats what you would prefer.

Sooo well balanced.  Nice thick malty mid section comes in at just the rigt time.  I do like to cut this one with some sharp cheese but she works well when I am doing the lawn etc... smells great and will not dissapoint.

12z bottle.  Amber gold hue.  White clinging head.  Hay, straw, yeast aromas.  Fruit notes in the nose.  Citrus hop flavor.  Light malt roast.  Good palate.  Bittersweet chocolate, citrus, floral hop finish.

12 oz bottle labeled bottled in October (Im guessing of last year since I pulled this out of the back of my fridge). Poured a kard orange/copper color with a large sized off white head. Aromas of light caramel and hops. Tastes of pine, citrus and some light caramel.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & tupalev -- courtesy of tupalev. Pours a clear copper with a spare white head. Mild earthy hops aroma. Slightly dissapointing flavour of malt, citrus hops and a touch of wood. This is just O.K.
Bottle.  Aroma is hops, almost like the most characteristic pale ale.  a little grungy.  Brown with a minimal head.  Tastes fizzy, salty, brine, barnacle.  Very new england.  Clam bread?

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, tupalev & jerc - courtesy of tupalev. Bright red-amber with a small head. Nice hop character in the aroma and flavour, pretty well balanced. Nice enough, I could drink a few without complaint, but nothing outstanding.

Bottle shared GregClow, Hogtown Harry, Blankboy, and Jerc - I picked it up a couple of months ago.  Dark orange, very little bubbly white head.  Some hops and malt in mild aroma.  Semi-sweet malt taste and hops.  A strong bready like quality to the whole beer.  Short finish.  A standard English pale, something I would drink but certainly would not go out of my way for.
Golden orange, small white head. Mild hops, resinous and chlorophylly. Resinous hops in the flavour are borderline astringent, touch of grapefruit. Lacking the malt to make it work. Touch thin.

Bottle (12ozl).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jerc, tupalev - courtesy of GregClow.  Poured dark copper with a smallish dimnishing off-white head.  Aroma is funky, almost vegetal malt and hops - a bit resiny.  Taste is quite bitter and harsh, but drinkable.

Creamy white head, with a golden amber body.  Slight fruit and pines in the aroma, but very minimal.  Heavy hops in the tasting as well as high carbonation, leaving the mouth somewhat dry.  An interesting combination for an English Pale and while not my personal favorite nothing to be ashamed of.
Pretty good all around, has a subdued hoppyness, has kind of a cheddar like aftertaste, not bad, but nothing too noteworthy.  A solid beer.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 On tap at Portsmouth Brewery on 05/15/2010. Clear copper amber body with a medium frothy white head. Sweet pale malt and floral hop aroma. Sweet floral and resiny hop flavor on a pale malt background. Medium body with moderate carbonation. 7/4/7/3/14 - 3.5

11/30/2005 - Amber color with a frothy ivory head that lingers. Lightly hoppy aroma. Roasted malt flavor with a light hoppy aftertaste. 6/3/6/3/12 - 3.0

Pours a reddish amber with a medium, lingering white rocky head that leaves a moderate amount of lacing behind. An aroma of malts with mild touches of hops. Tastes of toasted malts with mild hops on a medium body. A pretty plesent beer.
I got this in a bottle from my local beer-joint.   Pours a dark copper body with a small,  off-white head.   It has a slight citrus hop aroma.  Malty, with a slight bitter finish.  Drinkable.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2005 (12 oz bottle: Chevy Chase Liquors in Washington, DC) This is a well-balanced pale ale, but it seems pretty ordinary to me.  Its somewhat toasty, minimally sweet, and the hops is citrusy, grassy and moderately bitter for an overall flavor that is consistent from start to finish.  The nose is mostly just grassy hops with a hint of toast in the background.  Light-medium bodied, trending pretty close to medium, carbonation is good, and the beer is very clean.  The dark amber and hazy body is topped by a smallish off-white head that settles to a very wide ring while leaving a few large patches of lace on the glass.  I was expecting much more from this beer, and maybe I should try another bottle just to be sure, but I dont think its more than just an average pale ale.  I dont see what the fuss is about.

12oz. bottle. Dark amber color with a medium sized off white head. Citrus hop and biscuit malt aroma. The malt flavor hits me first, followed by a certain grassiness, finishing with a decent hop bitterness.

Pours a dark amber color with a creamy head that subsides quickly. Aroma is hoppy, has some honey and some wheat in it. Flavor is a tad bit bitter at first but the finish is smooth and sweet. It needs a few more hops to be a great pale ale but it already is a pretty good brew.

Bottle from dirtymike.  Thanks!  Pours a rich amber with a nose containing floral aromas and sharp hops.  Flavor is nice and floral, with biting hops.  A lingering smoke taste somehow appears in the finish.  Palate is coating.  This aint no session beer.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: clouded dark brown. aroma iswell, contaminated sour oak notesand yeasty. tasted is hopped up wheat., so angry and acidic in the finish. it burns a bit. lingering smoke taste that makes me think it is up to something., not bad, but interesting.

Clear dark amber body, nice offwhite head.  Modest malt aroma with just a little floral hops presence.  Hops element is more apparent in the taste accompaning roasted malt. Lightly metallic and bitter aftertaste.

bottle. copper body with a small, creamy, off-white head. mellow citrus hop aroma with some biscuit/crystal malt in the background. Quite a bit of orange hops in this one which kind of strikes me more as an APA rather than an EPA. there is also a generous bready malt component and a hint of chocolate towards the end. finish is long and bitter. pretty good

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2006 Pours amber orange with white creamy head, mostly diminishing. Aroma is floral with some caramels. Flavor is a good mix of hops and malt, not too strong either way. Finishes with a bit more hops. Texture is smooth, slightly watery. Finish short.

Aroma of orange hops and chocolate, some good malts too, opaque orange, a long lasting finger of custard head, some pretty lace also. Rich malt flavour, combined with a good helping of citrusy hops, with nutty and woody notes. Very well balanced, beautiful mouthfeel. Terrific!

Pours orangish-amber with a half-finger off-white head. Slow effervescence. Aroma of soapy hops and bready malts. Very nice malt flavor up front, with a good amount of hop bitterness at the end. Not over the top with either flavor.

Cloudy copper with minimal off-white head. Aroma leans toward malts, so the hop flavor is a nice surprise. The balance between the malts and hops provides sweet citrus flavor, earthy grains and a bitter aftertaste that is not overpowering. Clean and crisp with a medium body that expanded slightly toward full as the beer warmed. Enjoyable.
Pours copper with a straw like white head.  Smells of grapefruit and grass.  Tastes of dandelions, daisies and other wildflowers.

Bottle. Orange amber color with little head. Subtle hoppy nose with distinct toaste malt aroma. Flavor follows: subtle grapefruit hop sweetness and tang, with a balanced bitterness and smooth toasted malt finish. A subtle beer all around; well blended and a real delight.
Cloudy copper with some foamy white head. Nose is floral hops and not much else. Flavor is more of the same. Needed more balance and more malt.
Bottle. Pours copper color w/ large white bubbly head. nose is light hopps. Taste features light hopps, malt, and a grassy/earthy finish.

Pour is a nice deep orange but lacks any sort of head. Aroma is basically non-existant: maybe a little hoppiness but not much else. Some bitterness and a shrug of malt balance comes through in the taste profile but it really is not exciting. Not great, but drinkable.
brown beer smells like caramel. Very refreshing. The finish is very dry. A little bit too hoppy.
Cask (GBBF): Bronze with a beige head. Subdued hop nose. Nice sweet malty start with a long dry citric fruit finish. Medium bodied, quite refreshing, and not over the top. Nice session beer.
