Brown beer with a malty and caramel aroma and a slightly nutty and caramel flavour with a dry finish.  Overall a reasonable beer.

Pours deep red/gold with a short tan head. Slight barnyard above a toasted cereal, leafy hop, and light sweet caramel. Flavours are clean and earthy. Very soft carbonation. Woody and medicinal bitters. Faint tart berries at the end. Good.

Draught @ GBBF 2005: Golden coloured. Hazy. Light brown head. Is a bit hoppy in the nose. Some vague sweetness. Flavour is herbal, light floral and has some chocolate notes. Fruity bitter in the end with a light nutty touch. A bit ordinary

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense GBBF 2005.  This won best American cask ale at GBBF again - at the least the second time in three years, but for me it was very disappointing in its plainness.  Amber coloured with a pleasant hop aroma but a bit of a compost heap rotting smell.  The taste had some nice hop notes and a little caramel.  All very unspectacular sadly.

Cask at GBBF
Dark amber, typical American IPA hop nose, sweetish fruit but a really good long lasting satisfying hop finish

Pours a brownish orange body, slightly hazy. Aroma is a little bit fruity and spicy, but also slightly hoppy. That doesnt really describe it very well though. Earthy or doughy might be better. Finishes fairly sweet with some hop bitterness that lingers. Flavor is much better than the relatively weak aroma. I cant believe this is one of the best pale ales out there.
clear copper, off white head.  aroma of leafy, earthy hops with mild resin and a whiff of barnyard.  toasty malt and caramel flavours with mild orange and leafy pithy hop finish.  nice
Hazy brown body with off whiye head when poured from  my 12oz. bottle. The nose was balanced malts and hops, with yeast. Spices come out in the taste. Well done.

Semi-hazy bronze with a tiny, swirling, bubbly head.  Aroma leads with fresh hops along with elements of cotton, dryer sheets and whole wheat bread playing a supporting role.  Hops hit up front for flavor, then gently recede to a honeycomb sweetening.  Very much in line with a scaled back version of Smuttynoses IPA.  Some accents of gingerale and bran flakes, wrapping up with a dash of salt or citric oranges.  Dry and lively on the palate.  A decent pale ale.  Thanks to tpkenned for the Smuttynose connection!

Bottle. Pours hazy copper with little white head. Mostly hoppy flavors with some malts, but flavor doesnt last too long, probably because of way too much carbonation - a harsh and distracting on the tongue.
Bottle.  A copper pour with a slight thin white head.  Very hoppy but the hops fade fast.  Very flavorful pale.
Pours a golden reddish color with average head. Sweet yeast and hop aroma. Taste is a perfectly balanced mix of malts, hop and carbonation. Finishes clean and dry. Excellent Pale Ale.
Bottle: Spicy hop nose and a mild, nutty malt/caramel base, bready malt notes; sweet front end. slightly dry finish; not particularly flavorful; a fairly average pale, at best
Good color, not much nose to it. Good floral hops taste well balanced with sweeter malts. A really really well done pale ale. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2006 on tap- Pours a caramel head that hangs around well.  Color is copper-amber.  Taste is a bit on the sweet,fruity side, a little hoppy without the bitterness, nice.  

rerate-12oz bottle 3.7

(on bottle)NICE amber-brown colour, with a small tan head. The aroma is really plesant, lots of pear/apple and warm malts - caramel. Therefor the tart and harsh taste is a bit wild for this palat; the finish almost became metallic.

Of late I have been drinking lots of Smuttynose IPA, so I thought Id try this to compare- Ive had it many times but its been awhile.
The pour: coppery-amber with frothy head and lots of lacing.
The nose: nice blend of hops- no strong single hop character stands out (not screaming citrus or pine or grass) , but a nice balance. Maltiness and a subdued fruitiness from the yeast blend in as well.
The flavor: hoppy and malty up front, bitter with some caramel in the middle and a reasonably dry finish.
I prefer the more aggressive IPA, but then thats a different style. A solid well made pale ale from one of my favorite breweries.

Out of the bottle three months after bottled.       Coppery color threw me off because it is very light tasting.  Bright and refreshing, but almost too much so; I would like more of the hoppy taste to be more prevelant in this beer.   After taste is that of processed or "factory" hops and requires a glass of water near by.   Too bad you cant taste those hops going down since this is an overly malted Pale Ale.

Bottle. Light copper body with a decent white head that left some lacing. Nose:grassy hops, wheat toast, garden dirt and chocolate. Taste:citrus and grassy hops, wheat toast, caramel malt and apples. Smooth and very drinkable. Nice.

12 oz bottle pours amber cloudy with very little head.  Aroma is caramel malt and a little citrus.  Taste has much a much more earthy sense to it than American pale ales.  Lighter hops grace this and give it just a touch of citrus flavor.  More malty and full bodied than American Pale Ales...  Medium bodied and very drinkable on the palate..
bottled, amber color w/ small head.  the aroma is mainly hops, the flavor is hoppy but balanced w/ adequate amount of maltiness.

Crystal malt offers a strong caramel aroma with some mild, citrus, floral, earthy hop notes.  Very clear copper coloured body is topped by a finger of off-white, large-bubbled head that recedes to a partial cover. Fruity esters up front blend with floral and earthy hops and a fair bitterness with some caramel maltiness.  Medium light body with moderate carbonation.  Bottle (trade, May-2005) marked as brewed and bottled in February (I assume 2005).  Thanks, jah noth!

Definatly can tell the difference from an APA. This has a lot of earthy tones. Mild dry hopped aroma. Light brown color with an orange tint. No real head. Nice hoppy bite. Very different taste. Grassy. Drinkable pale ale.

Bottle.  Brewed and bottled:  01/05.  Red-copper pour with smallish light-tan head that leaves some lacing.  Aroma of citrusy hops, sweet malts and hints of spices.  A serious lack of body in this one.  Its all very dry, bitter hops.  Distinct absence of sweetness.  The bitterness is apparent immediately and lingers forever.  This isnt the good, tasty bitterness either.  Ill definitely need a glass of water after drinking this.  This is very dirty-tasting.  Like licking dirt or grass.

Pours a hazy light brown with a thick lacy tan head. Smells of light hops, a bit spicy and sour malt.

Taste is surprisingly good. Its hoppy, not overly so but assertive. Well balanced with a strong grainy malt taste. Apple-like yeasty flavors. Medium bodied with a persistent hoppy aftertaste. Crisp and smooth. Damn drinkable. as others have said, very good session beer. A very solid offering and a nice surprise. Does Smuttynose ever miss?

Mildly hazy amber/rosewood pour supporting a small dusky white head (which needed some urging to generate).  Fruity aroma with a toasty background.  Well balanced flavors of dried apricot, vanilla, a little toffee, malt and even a porter-like milk chocolate all backed up by a solid hop bitterness.  Flinty, clean and bitter finish.  This is a nice Pale which shares some of the flavor profiles with other Smuttynose ales (probably due to their house yeast).

bottle.  tarnished copper in color with a head that disappeared so quick I almost missed it.  a tangey, carbonated bite on the front end that fades to some malt and a bit of hops on the finish.  not quite as thirst quenching as I had hoped.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2005 Most pale ales seem to come across too sweet for my palate, not this one.  Poured a deep amber with a beautiful dirty white head that refused to quit that thickly  laced the glass.

  The aroma was hoppy and the taste was Gr Apple sweet to citrus pine hops quickly transitioning to dry and bitter.  The finish was definitely dry with just enough hop bitters.

Well done Smuttynose.

(bottle)  Pours light golden-brown.  Mahagony colored and cloudy in glass with small off-white head.  Small is strongly malty, rich, sweet like caramel, and reminiscent of roasted coffee.  Flavor is sweet and ends with nice medium bitterness that doesnt knock your wind out.  Body is medium to full, fairly smooth, and just a little watery.  Another good one from Smuttynose.

Bottle.  Poured a nice clear deep amber color with a small off white head.  The aroma was weak with the smell of citrus hops and some sweet malts.  The flavor of mild malts balanced fairly well with some citrusy hops.  Mouthfeel is somewhat thin to maybe medium bodied..lightly bitter and dry in the end.  I liked this better after about 2/3 of the way through.  My first Smuttynose ale...I need to try more.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2008 April 26, 2005; 12 oz. bottle. Clear, dark amber -- almost burnt orange pour.  Rapidly dissipating head leaves just a bit of lacing.  Initially fruity "hit" (as expected from Smuttynose), but I really like the malty undertones balancing this one, as the hops fly over the top into a bitter finish. Re-rate on Feb. 14, 2008: Going to bump up the "flavor" score a point . . . this is a truly-excellent Pale Ale.
[Cask at GBBF 2004] An orange beer with no head. The aroma is sweet and very hoppy, but also with notes of oranges. The flavor is very hoppy and grassy and it has a very bitter end.
Amber beer, very thin....classic pale.....hoppy then bitter.....no head....too boring to write anything more.....
Dark copper, musty aroma, some hops, caramel,  woody, earthy notes, pleasant hop finish, some citrus, notes of caramel as well.  Pretty good
Poured an amber color, with ligh lacing.  Smells of  malts and hops.   Body is thin like the rest in the smuttynose variety.  Sweet yet hoppy on the palate.

Bottle aged about a year, courtesy of goldtwins: Pours a clear copper with a lightly lacing off-white head.  Light green hoppy aroma with some dry caramel malt.  Body has a little sweetness but is thin and mostly bitter without much malty balance.  Sample is probably too old, but the beer still shows signs of weakness apart from aging.

Poured an amber color with a medium off white head.  Aromas of peach, caramel, and a lightly hopped.  The flavors were thin, as was the body.  Not much going on up front then middle and finish had some bitterness.

A floral hops aroma, a nice amber colour. Otherwise, a metalic taste and very dry not bitter not very flavourful at all. Bubbles, head fizzed out quickly. Could not finish. Harsh carbonation. Some malts, but didnt work
Amber body, small white head.  Aroma is faint, some slight hoppiness.  Flavor is nice but nothing spectacular, some citrusy hops and a bit of maltiness.  I thought this was rather average.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2005 Polar Beer Tour 2005

 Also a Draft. A decent PA, one I had a couple of on this trip. The body was a golden orange. The senses brought forth some crisply tart and bready characters, with a mild American and English hop edge in the finish. Grassy, lightly citric, subdued and mild for todays  Pale Ales spectrum. Good but forgettable.

Terrific brew which pours out a nice coppery color with a good-sized tan head which didnt completely leave.  The taste is awesome with an overall hops and malts dominance with an undercurrent of sweet fruitiness.  Finish is slightly bitter but pleasant.  Looking forward to drinking more!
Bottle: Pours a clear copper with smallish white head. Light aroma of fruit, hops. A little bit of orange in the flavor, light malt and hops. Touch of caramel. Good clean beer that goes down smooth.
Pours amber, smells malty, bready, sweet with hints of hops.  Taste is more hoppy, you can kind of taste some fruit in there.  Very clean, smooth aftertaste.
Amber copper color.  very smooth hop aroma.  Subtle.  Very drinkable and quite tastey.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2005   I thought this would be rated a little higher, because I am pretty impressed.  It pours a nice red color with a narrow head.  The aroma is malty with some pretty good hops.  Pleasantly surprising.  The flavor is very good.  It is bitter and malty.  Quite impressive indeed.  It has some citrus in it.  I think this beats a lot of other Pale Ales.  I like it.

Pours amber to nut brown with a small off-white head that mostly dissipates.  Caramel malt and yeast aroma with an orange hop nose.  Spotty lacing as you drink.  Buttery caramel and roasted malt flavor with a hop finish.  Fizzy and medium-bodied palate.

this was a good beer.  good hop flavor that wasnt overpowering.  i drank it straight from the bottle cuz im all class so i didnt observe the color or head but it smelled like hop goodness.  i could sip on this beer all day long
I think I prefer this to the Sierra Nevada, beautiful dark color and strong, almost IPA-like, citrus-hoppy nose.  Drinkable and rememberable.  What more do you want from a pale ale??
Nice pale ale, very tasty and smooth, hop flavor subtle, but welcoming.  Consistent to the last drop, unwaivering in delivery of crisp notes of warm maltiness and grain.  Good stuff.

Bottle pours deep rich amber, large frothy light tan colored head, attractive lacing, with very light carbonation. &nbsp Pale hop aroma, slight malts, a bit of grains as well. &nbsp Slight grain sourness immediately up front. &nbsp Minor hop flavor, buiscuity. &nbsp Decent body, medium mouthfeel. &nbsp Finishes very minor hop bitterness, with lightly roasted malts. &nbsp Not bad. &nbsp Thanks goes out to jah noth for the trade!

This one poured out a nice clear deep amber color with a small off white head. The head quickly dropped to a collar covering the beer and stuck around the rest of the time. The aroma was a bit weak with the smell of citrus hops rides a slightly sweet malt. The tastes of malt start this off before a citrus hoppiness follows. This is a bittersweet finish that comes in at the end that is quite pleasant. This one reminds me in part of an IPA in the same sense SNPA does. Good mouthfeel and carbonation. Overall a good beer that is a bit different for a Pale Ale and quite tasty.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2006 On tap at the portsmouth brewing...
Aroma:grapefruit hops..
Appearance:Clear orange,small head..
Flavor:Orange juice,grapefruit hops..

Pours an inviting tall head over a clear amber body that gives off a well balanced bouquet of caramel malt and hops.
Dry without being overly bitter, this is a little different, an intangible complexity where no component pushes to the front, letting you explore the tastes and body at will. Very nice.

Very pleasing cloudy copper color with average head.  Toffee and caramel malt aromas compemented by earthy hops.  Medium bodied with a mild acidic astringency that isnt so good.  Bread tries to come through, but doesnt fully develop.  A decent pale ale that leans toward the malt, but nothing to go crazy about.

Bottle - thanks to slob!  Pours rich copper color and slightly hazy with a moderate white head that mostly diminishes.  Aroma is predominantly malty, with a floral hop nose and some hnts of spice.  Flavor is spicy and hoppy up front, malty/hoppy in the middle with nice sweet maltiness coming on in the finish.  Medium body and prickly carbonation.  Nice pale ale.

This IPA head poured with a frothy head that slowly diappeared with lacing down the glass.  The aroma was enticing and the color a dark copper.  The taste was complex with hops and maltiness.  The aftertaste was bitter and lingered.
Solid, well made pale with all that I want and a whole helluva lot more of the good and much less of the half ass than many if not most of the middle of the road pale ales out there. A job well done.

Bottle, from Julios. Bottled in August. Good nose, nutty, carmel, lttle earthy,cocoa maybe?. Clean orangy brown color. Ok head that faded quickly. Bitter sweet flavors, Carmel, little hint of a baking chocolate, Whole wheat bread,little lemon or grapefruit. Thin body, lite creamy mouthfeel, bitter dry finish. Tasty brew, a long time favorite, I cant believe I took this long to rate it.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: This has a typical sweetish hop aroma but, otherwise, is quite soft and moderately bitter for a US pale. Now I see its down as an English style pale. Im not sure the style is that English, but it does have a well balanced, understated and rather classy appeal. Not nearly as upfront as some other US offerings, but rather nice. Cask, GBBF 2004.

Orange-copper body with significant carbonation and a soft, silky off-white head. Fresh citrus and floral hops. Fruity malts plus an interesting musty quality. Hoppy, dry flavor. A solid pale ale that strikes me as more American than English in style, but thats academic.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2004 Golden amber in color with a thin off-white head.  Sweet, fruity aroma....maybe along the lines of apricots?  Well-balanced....maltier than most pale ales.  Medium-bodied.  Overall, yummy.
Smuttynose has always been reliable for me. Hops are somewhat light, but enough to keep it interesting. It balances well with the malt sweetness. A quite enjoyable session beer.

Dark amber with a taller off white head. Earthy/woody malt aromas along with some mild fruit. Flavors of cocoa, light oak and peat. Mild herbal bitterness. A nice change of pace from the resent onslaught of IPAs, APAs and general over hopped brews.  Thanks to Falconeye8 for this brew.
on tap at big city in boston. looked nice and amber with a creamy head. curious aroma of autumn leaves and pickled onions. drinkable with a light dry finish. simple but well-made

New Holland had tons of head, Smuttynose didnt have as much. Thats ok because Smuttynose is a different style but nonetheless a very very good beer. Ive had two of this line previously and both were outstanding. This is no exception.  Of the English Style this is the 2nd best EPA Ive had to date.
Hazy orange-amber. Finger of beige foam. Earthy, fruity, malty aroma. Medium feel. Earthy flavour of malty (caramel, brown sugar, chocolate?), fruit (orange) & wood. Some diacetyl present

Some will say this brew is boring and yes, theres nothing exactly special about it. However, it is a very satisfying English-style Pale Ale. Aroma is malty. Taste is mildly bitter with a solid amount of hops, caramel malt and some citrus. Mouthfeel is fantastic; full, round and very creamy. Extremely solid brew. Recommended.

My favorite domestic beer. This beer has just the right balance between the sweet tasting malt and the hop bite. Just bitter enough to satisfy, but had a sweet pleasant aftertaste, that makes this quite a complex brew. Another great Smuttynose beer.
not a very floral pale ale but very tasty with a nice bitterness and citrus essence.

Pours a darker amber color, slightly cloudy with a nice white head that falls quickly. Aroma is very fruity with a faint hop aroma. Taste was malty and sweet at first with a fruity flavor. Ended slightly bitter. Very nicely balanced pale ale.

12oz bottle, 05.18.04  Pours dark coppery-amber-gold, cloudy; smallish head, quick fade, slight lace.  Aromas are fruity, citrusy hops, bag of jelly beans.  Flavors are light, white toast; tart fruit candy.  As the description asserts, the middle lasts well into the finish and beyond.  Sourdough pancakes.  Finish is sharp and nicely bitter, and bakers cocoa(?).  Palate is balanced nicely for a English PA, not too astringent, not overly malty.  Smuttynose knows beers.

pours a reddish brown color.  hoppy and citrus smelling beer.  somewhat bitter tasting.  this- along with the old dog brown was not too impressive.  id drink it again, but i think id rather drink one of the bombers i got.
Pours dark straw/copper with decent head.  Aroma of hops and malt.  Tastes malty, hoppy, fruity, with a crisp hop/floral/fruity finish.

Slightly hazed amber body, light frothy light tan head. Light hop and bread aroma. The flavor is quite bready with a nice little bit of a hop bite towards the end. The palate is quite delightful, for a session beer. Not too shabby.

ahhhh - there is nothing better in the world after a 12 hour trip from Germany to NJ than sitting after a quick shower in JoeVees garden in the sun and having a relaxed first beer!!!! Nice chocolate smoked nose. Hoppy with some sweet toffee untertones. Nicely balanced.
An aroma of hops and caramel. A flavor of hops and caramel. A decent pale ale, not more, not less.

Pours dark brown off the tap. The flavor of this beer isn't very assertive. Maybe a hint of caramel in there. Kind of dark and heavy compared to other pale ales I've had. It's different, not to my liking.

Decent head with almost no carbonation.  Tart and hoppy aroma.  Very hoppy.  Slightly floral with a touch of fruit.  Color is a dark amber.  Good hop flavor along with a bit of roastyness.  Almost like burnt toast.  Finish is roasty also and leaves a nice bitter aftertaste.  A very good pale ale and another very good beer from Smuttynose.

Crystal clear, copper-colored ale with a small, creamy, off-white head.
Bisquity, citrusy aroma with notes of milk chocolate. Malty flavor with big fuggle or cascade hops for balance. Medium-bodied with a fizzy mouthfeel and a lengthy, bitter finish. Recommended.

Pleasant but not brilliant floral, fruity aroma.  Dark orange/red in color with a tiny, white head; very little significant lacing.  Malt flavor is sweet and long-lasting, and there is a good hop hit toward the end.  Nice, fairly rick body.  Having recently been drinking stuff from the likes of Otter Creek, Harpoon, and Sam Adams, this is a refreshing and more positive experience.

Nice clean and refreshing floral hop nose.  Looks like a pretty tight pale.  Cloudy medium orange/amber color with a thick pillow-like head that looks fluffy as a cloud.  Very strong and bitter hop presence with kind of a sourdough taste.  Could use just a little more malts in the mix for a better balance.  Not a bad pale ale though after it breathes a bit.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2009 Oranges twinkling through a heavy caramel firmament...A luscious, unfiltered body of grassy, leafy hops achieves impressive balance with the prevalent fruity sweetness...Although aroma is somewhat lacking compared to the full flavor and body, this is one very good pale ale I would like to know more intimately...Could have more identity though...

UPDATED: APR 3, 2004 (DRAFT) Light brown ale with a hoppy resinous aroma. However, the taste is hoppy but more like german hops, very sharp,and good malts. medium body.

04/03/04: The hoppy character of the beer comes well with the bottle, lots of grapefruits, very floral and resinous, with a good body...initially rated 7-3-6-3-13 on tap in Potsdam but now its 7-3-7-3-15, bottled.

A fantastic pale al from a decent New England microbrew.  Bold, delicious hops; rich, copper color.  Very smooth upon the palate.  Strong finish with memorable hops lingering.  Note to self: look for more from this brewery!

Pours a full bodied amber brown with a large eggshell head, decent duration and nice lace.  Aroma is sweet and hoppy.  Flavors are mild grassy hops with a nice nutty taste and a slightly sweet finish.  A bit watery mouthfeel that fades to a lingering nutty dry finish.  Great, easy drinking pale.

Hazy deep amber,beige head. Nose is  malt with light hops Good malt with a hop finish that is longer than it is strong. Slightly piney
I quite like this.  Thanks Cap Flu !!!

Poured with a small head that faded fast. Orange amber color that was cloudy but that was because it was unfiltered and had the yeast in the beer. Caramel malt aroma with some hops in the background. Thinner body than what I was expecting. Some malty flavors with some hop flavors and bitterness in the finish. Not a bad english style pale ale but I have had better.

A great pale ale. Very malt forward but evenly matched round for round by the assertive hop backbone. Full bodied with a crisp, dry finish. Amber/Red with a nice head and fresh, mildly sweet, floral aroma.
Nice copper color with a diminishing head. Light hoppy aroma. Nice smooth taste with some hops and a floral taste. Pretty decent. Kind of bitter, but not too much. Fairly decent!

Deep copper.  Nose is very sweet and malty, akin to a brown ale.  Continues to be very malty in flavor, a bit of scotch character to it.  Lots of caramel and toffee in the flavor.  Definite hops at end, sharp and bitter.  Ends a bit cookie-ish and bready.  Bit unpleasantly soapy.

Pais $1.09 for a single 12-oz.

Medium orange to brown in color, small, frothy head.

Decent aroma- smells bitter, if bitter has a smell.


MMMM... this tastes good. Bittersweet, slight bite, but smooth, and very drinkable. This would be a good session beer, or a nice refershing summer beer. Thumbs up to this one.
one of the most pleasurable american pale ales i've had.  malty, smooth, with an appetizing and refreshing taste of those american hops.  can't wait to try more stuff by this brewer
This beer lacked all of my favorite things in a beer.  It would be a good introduction to a new beer drinker.  Just to lite for me.
Light brown color with nice light tan head. Sharp citrus hop taste well balanced by nice mellow caramel finish.
Very nice fruity aroma. The flavor is a bit fresh and citric, then goes to a bitter and fruity finish. Found notes of elder flower in this one.
Deep copper, almost brown color. Nice hop and malt aroma. Flavor was earthy and malty with a nice dose of hops, bittersweet. Medium body. I'd drink again.

I don't know about "the flavor of freshly-baked bread", but I can say that this is a pretty good beer. Nice copper coloring with a sweet-hoppy taste. I'll buy this again. The only bad part about the beer was the aroma. I can't put my finger on it, but it just doesn't smell all that appealing.
copper color, no real head. aroma is very grainy, slightly fruit, with an earthy quality. flavor is more fruity

Pours a hazed reddish-orange with a sturdy off-white head. The aroma is comprised of fruit and hops. The taste is predominantly hops but also has fruit, and some hints of malt and yeast. There is also a hint of soil. The mouthfeel is a little bitter but is drinkable. Decent pale ale.
Darkish orange color with a white head. Nice hops. Nice Aroma. A good Pale Ale.

Very deep copper/amber, almost red. Ecru head is very creamy and long lasting. Sharp citrusy hop, toast and roasted nuts in the nose. Restrained zingy hops give way to mellow almost-burnt toast and roasty almost-coffee flavors. The mouthfeel is full and creamy, almost buttery. A spike of metallic hop followed by coffeground bitterness in the mild yet lasting finish. This beer seems confused, with no real dominant character, and having more elements of a brown than a pale, yet failing to be either.

The nose is well balanced.  You can smell the hops, but they don't overpower the grassy sweetness.  The beer is very cloudy in the glass.  There is a LOT of sediment in there - is this supposed to be there?  This is the 2nd smuttynose beer where I've had sediment problems (the other was Big A IPA)  It tastes kind of burnt at first, followed by some hops and a fruity/bitter aftertaste.

(Bottle) Pours a thin, creamy, white head na d an orange-copper body. Nose of full-on hops! Absolutely beautiful beer. Flavours of cascade and chinook hops (yes - I checked their website!) and a tangy finish. This has to be one of my favourites! Ever so drinkable...

amber with staying thin white head that laces.  The hop aroma is distinctive but I guess I am still not an expert on the variety - think it is centennial or willimette.    
a bit like DFH Shelter pale but I like the finish of this beer more.  I think this is miscatagorized as an EPA and should be APA.

Dark coppery orange color, decent lasting head.  Aroma a good nose of roastiness, a bit of whole wheat bread.  Flavor was definitely centered on malt, but not sweet by any means.  Definite roast flavor, with a bit of the tang that is produced by this.  Earthy hop underpinnings, a very faint hint of fruit to round it out.  Solid.
[Cask conditioned] Copper coloured. Fruity and slightly hoppy aroma. Mild hop flavour.
This brewery proves as adept with hops as they are with malt. Easy to like pale ale. Sweet up front mellow in the middle with a nice dry finish. Tastes like another...
This beer has a mildly assetive hop flavor that is nicely balanced by the malt and fruity yeast.  Amber with a persistent white head.  Pretty good but not dynamite.

Pours a 90% transparent copper with a hint of redness and a very robust and frothy white head with very attractive lacing.  Aroma is of hops and barley, maybe a little sour note.  Mmmm...mouthfeel is marvelous.  Start is sort of sweet, which turns into a much hoppier flavor in the middle, only to have it drop off into a very mild and smoky finish.  This one is decent, but I wish it had a tad bit more bite to it.  Either way, a very good brew.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2003 Great brew but not my cup of ale.Malty/west coast vibe/thin.Some redeming hops and malt(honey sweet)/good quality beer I didn't care for enough.Nice amber appearance.Very smooth and better than I thought the first time around.
Nice Ipa. Very well balanced flavor. Its made with cascade hops, but they are not overpowering. It has a hop crispness to it.  Copper colored. I thought it was enjoyable.
Fruity hop aroma. Copper color with a small head. Flavor is of spicy hops, just a tad too thin, but a decent pale.

Pretty nice amber color with a tiny head, okay lacing down the glass. Flowery sweet in the nose. Citrusy floral sweetness on the tongue. Just a little too thin for me. We have a good no frills Pale Ale here. One beer to have around on hot summer nights. Would love to try this ale on cask!
Seemed watered down af first, but then the hoppy finish grew more prononcued it was a good pale ale, but there was nothing unique about it.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2003 Bottled. Deep mohagany color, very well balanced flavor. Good hoppy edge that doesn't overpower. I am not a huge Pale Ale fan, but this one I can tollerate. Re-rate: This one is more than tollerable, it's GREAT!
Good APA, although advertised as a EPA. Nice Cascade hop nose. Malt is well balanced with American hops. Would be better with English Noble hops. The American citrusy notes lower my rating a bit.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Quite a nice beer. Aromatic and smooth and quite rich for a pale ale. Finish is mildly bitter.

I think the guy behind the bar said this won best draft beer at the GBBF. Yeah, i guess it was pretty tasty. Aromatic hops. Nice soft palate. Sweet and hoppy, spicey, orangey, piney, pretty tasty actually (Cask-GBBF 03')
bottle. Good - starts off with a good hop taste with the malts showing halfway.
Bottled. Nice EPA. Nothing special. Nice slight bitter finish.
This is a nice pale ale.  One can definitely taste the English influence to this fine ale.

Medium orange brown color. Medium head. Aroma is fruity and sweet. A light bodied Pale Ale. Malts are nutty and slightly sweet. Hops are grapefruity and piney. Middle of the road Pale Ala. A touch thin and a little watery. Mouthfeel is a little thin. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter with a hint of grapefruit.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2003 Nice reddish color with a thin white head. Palate is very smooth, although maybe a little thin. The aroma and flavor both remind me of Bass, only with quite a bit more hops. A very nice beer.

Sorry boys but I'm not a fan of bitter beers. This one had a little too much hops for me but in keeping with this style of beer. Ruby/amber color, thin white head strong hoppy aroma. Heavy on the hops with a slight undercurrent of malt. Good if you're into this type of beer, but not for me.

I'm not a raving advocate of hoppy beers, but this beer didn't put me out. I suppose it'd go better with food than as a standalone. Color is red copper. Aroma is a sharp hop, and the hop flavor does border on piney.

A quite decent American pale ale with lots of good hoppy bitterness over a strong malty taste.  Not floral, not west coast citric, but good hops.  No "baked bread" taste  that's more of a wheat beer kind of thing.

Quite delicious for a pale ale, with noticable hops and groovy malts. The palate is smooth and easy. The color is a dark ruby sparkle. Quite unique for a style I often find boring and difficult to rate.

Not much to remark on- the body was an interesting amber hue with a very slight head.  Aroma was light and floral.  Flavor was floral, slightly bitter, and balanced by light malty tones.  Undistinguished.
As Pale Ales go this one is ok.  Like most of that genre the grapefruit flavor outweighs all else.  It is an attractive beer in apperance but not one I will go looking to purchase again.

An odd beer experience. This is the 2nd of 3 Shoals Pale ales in my smuttynose samplerpack. Pours with a nice red orange hue. Puny head almost immediately disappeared. (First bottle had zero head) Aroma has nice hint of hops to come. First sip - pretty good hop bite. Second and so on, hops fade. Body is very thin and watery. Very low malt flavor. Flavor seems to degrade as quickly as the head vanished. Find myself not really caring if I drink it or not. Just seems like a beautiful batch of hopwater. I give it high marks for looks, but average to low for most every other category. Would not buy again. Generally disappointed with the smuttynose beers so far except for the robust porter which was quite good.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2003 Pours a nice ruby dark brown color with medium white head. Hoppy aroma and bite. Light-medium body, soft, some malt chewyness, bit of citrus also. Finish is a little too bitter for my taste. Rerate: after finishing the six pack, I've come to like this more, not quite as bitter as I thought before, nice brown bread flavors, moerately complex. Enjoyable.
Decent beer, good overall taste, small head, light ale, brownish amber like ale.

Nice dark amber colour with a fluffy off-white head. An odd colour for an EPA but definately welcome. The aroma is a bit hoppy but more overpoweringly malty, just as any English Pale Ale should be. Lighter bodied and a bit watery in taste, but some residual malt and hops in the palate but other than that, a mediocre English style Pale. I bought this at Chevy Chase Wine & Liqour in Washington, in a standard twelve ounce bottle.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2003 Not your ordinary pale!  Filtered.  Deep, rich color, floral nose, zesty hop flavor with a strong lemony bitterness.  Very full bodied.  Reminiscent of Liberty Ale - it's richer, but not as carbonated.  Very good!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2005 2003 bottleReddish amber hue.  Pleasant citrus aroma with some malt.  Cascade hops initially moderately strong, but evens out quickly and a mild malt flavor, that reminded me of graham crackers rounds out the palate.  This beer was from the bottle and was exceptionally well balanced.  No problem with carbonation.  Hops do not last as long, and the malt flavor is a nice change.  Beer presents a very warm, drinkable texture and though the beer is not strikingly unique in any way, it is simply an impressively made beer.  I did not find the bitterness that was spoken of by several people, though the body was a little less full than I would like in a pale ale.  A great rendition of the EPA, could even handle more malt.  7/3/7/3/142005 draught  Theres a good rustic, minerally and hay-like hops and malt interplay here, grainy, lightly fruity and very crusty-baked bread-like, but I cant say much about the malt sweetness.  I guess they arent aiming for much of it.  Just too dry and attenuated feeling for me.  Lightly acidic/astringent almost.  7/3/6/3/13

Amber pour with a medium white head, mostly diminishes and leaves little lacing.  Aroma is mildly malty (caramel, biscuit), mildly floral hops.  Flavor starts with the mild caramel and biscuit, middle is clean, ends lightly hoppy.  Body is medium, light carbonation.

Poured with barely any head and a brownish/amber color.  There was a slight malty nose (although my sniffer isn't 100%) and a nice malty taste with a nice hoppy / sweet malty finish.  Nice beer although it could have used more carbonation!
Definitely not an APA, but rather an English Pale Ale whose hops caress you gently.  Nose is quite faint.
Boston Beer Summit 2003: Colored a murky brown with a soft and hoppy aroma, this one has a hoppy assault and a bitter leave.  Not bad, but not outstanding.

Nice amber appearance with a
winey aroma.  A warm feeling in mouth 
with some hops. 
A nice Pale Ale, however I enjoy IPA's for 
a better after taste than this beer.
A very crisp pale ale, but not very hoppy for a pale ale.  Hints of citrus, somewhat skunky aroma.  Dark amber color, little head around the sides of the glass.  Dry, malty.
I liked this one.  pours a  beautiful amber/maroon color.  It tastes  bitterly gwood!

This is a pretty darn good pale ale.  Light copper in color with a slight lacing.  Aroma is mostly of hops.  This has a nice malt backbone, which makes way in the middle for the moderate hoppiness, but then returns again to join in harmony with the hops in the finish.  The long-term of the finish, however, has an slightly unenjoyable bitterness to it.  Overall a decent pale ale.  I like these smuttynose people.

I'm thinking that all their products are good.  The real test is if the "regular" beers are up to par, which this one is.  Slightly cloudy amber gold, with a fluffy white head.  Good head retention.  Aroma is mostly a spicy hoppiness, with a light estery fruitiness.  Very well balanced, with a good deal of the hops coming out in the finish.  Awesome.  My only complaint is that I'd like less carbonation.  Kind of kills some of the maltiness.
Nice amber color. Good head. Slightly sweet malt balanced by hops. Hints of fruit. I agree with the rater who said this would be a good session beer.
Beautiful amber body topped with a medium thick white head and good lace.  Sweet hoppy aroma with lemony notes.  Slightly sweet very hoppy flavor with lemony accents. Medium bodied and slightly dry.
Has a nice amber color and a fruity smell.  Taste is malty and finishes mildly bitter.  Overall nothing special...

Copper pour with a wispy head that lingers. Nice hop nose with both floral and citrus coming through.This is a really good brew. Nice hop crispiness but the malt backbone is never far from the taste buds. The one thing I would like is a little more body. Still this would make a great session/everyday drinker. Thanks to hopsrus for this one.

This is a great looking beer.  Nice looking copper color with excellent effervescence (but poor head).  Sweet malt and citric hops in the nose, duplicated in flavor: complex, juicy, fine, divine and on time.  Long, dry and suitable bitter finish.  On the whole, reminiscent of Anderson Valley ESB and Troegs ESB.  Good stuff.

Bottle. Rusty bronze colour , short lived head with moderate natural condition. Aroma was very hoppy along with malt. Tasted like a mouthfull of raw barley with a balancing good hop flavour and a finish that lingers, becoming husky and dry.

Cloudy copper appearance with a head that just does not go away. Very sweet, fruity, malty aroma and taste. Very easy drinking, but lacks the hop presence to be considered a classic. Never thins out and is a good beer down to the bottom of the bottle. Solid pale ale.

Hazy copper color with a lasting white head, especially on the edges.   Lacing happening.   Citrus pine aroma, easy drinking.   Hops do come out in the lingering finish.   I could drink many of these in a row.
GABF notes say: Hoppy, OK.

well made pale.
hazy copper color,  dense long lasting head that left a sheet of lace. floral citric hop aroma.
malty body with a sweet caramel base . hasa redeeming bitter hop finish.
Moderate hops.  Hints of citrus.  A decent pale ale.
Hazy orange with a creamy head that left nice lace all the way down the glass and a subtle, fruity nose.  There are lots of hops with a nutty, citrus taste.  I found it a little thin.  A decent ale.

Sweet, hoppy aroma. Floral and fruity, with a hint of malt and brown sugar. Small, foamy off-white head atop clear reddish-brown body. Med-heavy fizz and soft watery body. Soft bitterness and quite hoppy. Nutty-bitter finish and after. A good EPA.
Hoppy, rich fruit aroma.  first flavor of light smoke/roast.  Very red tint, with thin/little head.  Slightly limp.  Typically bitter finish.  Pretty solid pale ale.
Dark opaque orange color, medium head that sticks around. Light hop aroma and flavor. Definitly a good session beer.
A good pale ale.  Moreish, with toffee notes and an impressive and long dryness.  Has a "chewyness" similar to Worthington White Shield.
An unfiltered gem and a musthave if youre in the area.Fruity/malty,hops stay with you till the bitter end.
copper-reddish rold hue.  fruity and roasted grain aroma. caramel malt flavors. Bitter dry finish, nice hops.
excellent pale ale, love the brewery!! somewhat sweet, and nice head, very  refreshing!
Not enough hop flavor and aroma.  Somewhat toasty but needs more hop balance.  An OK pale ale but lacks the PNW flavor that I love.  Very much an English Pale Ale.
A decent English pale ale.  A little on the thin side with a strong malt character.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2008 Rerate, from bottle in 2007. Still a fine malty EPA, with a nice spicy hoppiness. Not as impressive as I once thought. Original: I am very impressed by this pale. It is certainly English-style, as the body-supplying malts give an amazing depth. I have never given a 10 for aroma until now...the hops are evident, but the soft malt calls...In flavor, it is highly hopped, but defines balance. Yes there is that bitter grapefruit, and it isnt just the tongue and mouth that get it...you feel it in your whole head, deeply, and not just dry-hopping here. Wonderful beer.

text:
5/19/02Perhaps it was the fact that I consumed a six pack quickly while tired; perhaps it was that I knew I had to work in 5 hours time; or maybe it could have been that I was in the process of getting told how the woman Im going nuts over has no interest whatsoever in me; but whatever the case may be, I wasnt concentrating as well as I might be on the finer points of this well-received brew.  Nonetheless, I feel compelled to say that I found the nose weak; the earthy/herbal components that others have cited were noticeable, but not balanced with much in the way of sweetness or malt; and I thought the finish too bitter and thin.  Not terrible (I did enjoy the six), but Id have to try it again under better circumstances to say anything more than ehhh.

6/26/02 Well my lifes no better, but this beers improved a bit in a month.  Some time off from rating helps, maybe.  Found some interesting cocoa there, and the hoppiness more pronounced.  Not bad at all.

Comes out swinging with the hops - sharp, distinct, spicy in nose and mouth.  Reminds me of fermenting hay - you know, from a fine lush field thats been cut and maybe rained on, lying there stewing powerfully in the sun. When I catch my breath to notice the malt - when the malt catches up, as it were,  Im a bit nonplussed - some nuttiness, perhaps, but not enough complexity to handle the big opening.
deep gold/copper color.  thinner body, medium maltiness.  long hoppy finish.  above average, but not by much!
BORING!!!! Engish-style Pale Ale my ass. How about, boring-ass attempt at a style that every damn American brewer feels like they have to try. think outside the box you morons!
A kind of dirty taste. Not bad, really, just a real earthy edge to it. Cool Label, too.

A very pleasant American pale ale.  I found the finish to be nicely rounded, and not too bitter as one may anticipate at first.  I look forward to drinking again, although it does not hold up admirably to salty food.

A nice copper color with a somewhat off-putting mildewy aroma.  The flavor was delightful, though.  It has a very drinkable hoppiness.  Smooth and lovely -- well rounded.  It was definitely a surprise.

A bit of hops in the aroma, but its very faint.  The hoppiness comes to the fore in the flavor, although oddly enough, they seem like they dont stand out.  The head nicely laces atop a beautiful copper body.

Clear, copper colored. Thin head and lace. Nose of deep malt, earthy hops. Low carb, creamy, smooth and clean. Big malts, earthy hops, touches of peat, nuts and something I cant put my finger on. Good stuff, reminicent of Tom Paine. Thanks Psych!
Aroma reminded me of fruit juice, and was unfortunately weak.  Flavour was very good though - spicey, earthy, with gentle finish.
very tasty, not much aroma,, but it is rich and malty, a wonderful palate and finish. pleasant spiciness.

Cloudy colored, hoppy aftertaste, on the whole a very nice beer. (No points for it, but great looking bottle design, and cap reading make mine a smutty was pretty cool) Little head, tastes like a homebrew, but not too foamy, wonderfull on the whole. Slight bitter taste, but great finidh smooth yet complex. Only bought a single but will buy more for next time I get together with beer loving friends. Highly recommended.

rich orange color with a medium haze.  generous cushion of lingering suds. the aroma leaps to greet you like a happy golden retriever. orange zest and something that reminds me of gutting a halloween pumpkin, the seeds maybe.  grapefruit tanginess leads the flavor, dry and full bodied, very cleansing, but its the aroma that stays with you, just like that faithful retriever.

Aroma is too fruity and is reminiscent of a sour peach.  Nice color but the bitter aftertaste dominates the taste buds abd almost makes one forget about the initial flavor.  On a whole, it just smells and tastes too acidic.
Nice session beer
Amber with a clearly Pale Ale nose.  Intense Pale Ale taste.  A very good one, very typical of the kind.  A definite hit from this brewery!
Fruity, hoppy nose.  Copper color.  Nicely balanced hop bitterness.

Americna pale? This is all English, folks.  Orangey dark red hue; earthy malts, what I believe to be fuggles, bitter chocolate, plums and maybe a touch of peat on the nose; medium body; earthy palate, bark-like flavours, herbal bitterness, dark unsweetened chocolate; finishes bittersweet.

Golden orange, with a thick creamy head, grapefruit hop aroma, grapefruit flavour with some caramel malt underneath, which lingers on the finish.  Night as dry as a typical APA, nor as bitter, but quite good.

Nice malty backbone with a Cascade juicy bite on top. I noticed this on tap and now in the bottle but theres a weird herby flavor (sage, savory) underneath. Its interesting, not as disturbing as I once thought. Some nice malt notes and a very well  balanced pale.
One of the better ales from my home state. Clerly a favorite of many.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2006 12oz. bottle:  This one pours a clear amber color.  There was very little off-white head to it.  Somewhat weaker aroma, yet still pleasant.  Some floral notes, as well as a hint of caramel malts.  The taste has a bit of a grapefruit hoppiness to it, without being overly bitter.  Decent malt body.  A good beer.
Nice copper color.  Thin head.  Excellent citrusy spicy aroma.  Crisp flavor - plenty of nice hop flavor and big round malty mouthfeel.  Excellent balance.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2010 courtesy of fiulijn - hazy dark amber colour with a hugely foamy beige head; nice lacework; a fair resiney hoppy nose with notes of hazelnut, a bit buttery; low carbonation and very smooth, a gentle bitterness, hoppy aftertaste with a touch of herbs, mint and hazelnut

A nice pale: Its clear and
crisp. A superior example of
an American pale.
Good as pale as go, Im not overly impressed. Decent malt nose and a fair hop crispness. Clean, fresh, but a little on the light side for me. A good session beer non the less.

Unfiltered Pale Ale.  Very hoppy, and the yeast gives it an extra bite that I cant put my finger on.  Ive never tasted anything like this before.  If you like hazy beers (as in, Hefe hazy), and Pale Ale, this is a must try.  Very interesting, and very good.
